summary: Nature, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04081-6Ocean temperatures well below freezing in Earth’s deep-past glacial phases imply some very salty waters.

summary: Nature, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00119-5Bonds between same-sex individuals help apes and monkeys to manage conflict and strengthen alliances, especially in dry habitats and predator-rich landscapes.

summary: Nature, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00068-zAn open letter organized by US-based researchers who work in Greenland opposes any takeover of the territory.

summary: Nature, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00085-yDo your New Year resolutions include a plan to leave higher education? These researchers explain how to reinvent your career.

summary: Nature, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00083-0Twenty-five years after its launch, the online encyclopedia now competes with chatbots — but its creator still has faith in humans when it comes to sourcing facts.

summary: Nature, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00084-zUniversities, governments, academics, health-care providers and students must work together to ensure timely access to suitable mental-health support.

summary: Nature, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00115-9A Chinese reactor has jumped a hurdle that’s held nuclear fusion back for decades. Plus, astronauts are being evacuated from the International Space Station and AI chatbots in therapy make claims of abuse.

title: Closing the carbon mismatch
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01906-xClosing the carbon mismatch

title: Extreme weather event accountability
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01904-zExtreme weather and climate-related disasters are escalating in severity, frequency, and impact. Global climate policy must embed formal mechanisms that attribute these events and their consequences to major carbon emitters, ensuring accountability and accelerating the implementation of effective mitigation strategies.

title: Mechanical rejuvenation of senescent stem cells and aged bone via chromatin remodeling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68387-3Senescent bone marrow stem cells were revealed to exhibit reduced intracellular force, and optimized mechanical stimulation restores this force, enhances FOXO1 chromatin accessibility, and reverses cellular senescence and bone aging.

title: Precise excision of expanded GGC repeats in NOTCH2NLC via CRISPR/Cas9 for treating neuronal intranuclear inclusion disease
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68385-5NIID is a neurodegenerative disease caused by GGC repeat expansions within NOTCH2NLC gene. Here, authors develop a precise gene-editing therapy that effectively treats the disease in multiple models.

title: Harnessing acoustic topology for dynamic control of liquid crystal defects
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68001-yTopological defects can be used to encode functionalities in soft matter systems. Here, authors dynamically reconfigure an acoustic lattice to create programmable topological defect arrays. The resulting velocity fields and steady acoustic streaming realign the director, enabling reversible control of defect properties and their translation.

title: Non-polar nanocluster confinement engineering realizes high capacitive energy storage in Pb-free high-entropy relaxors
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68301-xThe authors reconcile the conflict between polarization and hysteresis by confining polarization response of non-polar nanoclusters in high-entropy relaxors, thus improving the energy storage properties of multilayer ceramic capacitors.

title: The interconnected wirings between medial prefrontal cortex and claustrum and their governing roles in the methamphetamine reward memory in male mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68009-4The precise brain circuits underlying drug reward memory remain unclear. Here, authors show that the interconnected wirings between medial prefrontal cortex and claustrum contribute to the encoding and retrieval of methamphetamine reward memory in a pathway-specific manner.

title: Cultural diversity of religion across 117 countries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67671-ySocieties differ widely in cultural values across the world. Here, the authors show that religious values display the greatest cross-country diversity, exceeding that of comparable values, such as values concerning family, work, or politics.

title: Propellane-free access to bicyclo[1.1.1]pentanes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68309-3Bicyclo[1.1.1]pentane (BCP) is a valuable three-dimensional bioisostere of benzene. This Perspective highlights emerging, propellane-free strategies to access multisubstituted and bridge-functionalized BCP derivatives, assesses their scope and limitations, and outlines remaining challenges.

title: Quantum enhanced metrology based on flipping trajectory of cold Rydberg gases
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67921-zDissipative many body systems provide quantum-enhanced sensitivity to external near gap-closing points. Here, the authors demonstrate record sensitivity in a Rydberg-atomic platform in correspondence of folded hysteresis trajectories under external microwave driving

title: State dependent ice-sheet resonance under Cenozoic and future climates
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03135-xGradual cooling or warming of the atmosphere, combined with strong ocean-driven basal melt, could have led to major changes in the periodicity, phasing, and asymmetry of past ice sheet growth and decay, according to an ensemble of 500-kyr long ice sheet simulations.

title: Photoacclimation contributes to Arctic primary production under sea ice and around the subsurface chlorophyll maximum
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03181-zArctic chlorophyll content under ice and around the subsurface chlorophyll maximum is several times higher than surface open-water regions, resulting in a phytoplankton growth rate beneath the ice comparable to open-water areas, according to global ecosystem model simulations.

title: Abrupt trend change in global mean sea level and its components in the early 2010s
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03149-5The early 2010s sharp change observed in sea level and components is likely due to internal climate variability, although increased radiative forcing may have also played a role, according to analysis of altimetry-based global mean sea level data.

title: Between-plant interactions in Scots pine are not impaired by air pollutants
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03175-3Air pollution does not impair neighbour-induced defence against herbivory in Scots pine seedlings, but it affects photosynthesis, stomatal conductance, and volatile organic compound emission, shown at the Free-Air Diesel and Ozone Enrichment platform.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03140-0Thermal modelling and numerical calculations suggest that potentially eruptible magma is present at a depth of around 4 km beneath Campi Flegrei, but that the magma reservoir volume is currently smaller in comparison to the last eruption in 1538.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03006-5Recent Dense Shelf Water outflow from the Dibble Polynya in East Antarctica followed a reduction of Antarctic Bottom Water upstream, according to hydrographic observations.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03023-4Marine darkwaves can be used to compare patterns and ecological consequences of episodic light reduction in marine ecosystems, according to application of the framework to both in situ and satellite based light irradiance data from California and New Zealand.

summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-026-68310-wMechanically reconfigurable mechanisms offer a cost-effective, low-complexity approach to build high-capacity multiplexing wavefront modulation devices, yet current studies achieve insufficient channel numbers for practical applications due to limited mechanical transformations and suboptimal optimization models. title: Room-temperature high-efficiency spin injection via van der Waals tunnel contact
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67989-7Researchers developed a simple, industry-compatible method using an indium buffer layer between cobalt and 2D materials to form vdWs tunnel contacts. title: Elasto-magnetic instabilities for amplified actuation and mechanical memory
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68225-yHere the authors utilize magnetic attraction and elastic tension to create instabilities that amplify vibrations and induce inertia-driven hysteresis. title: The urgent need for African research collaboration on medicine quality
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67430-zSubstandard and falsified medicines are a global health threat. title: Universal modulus-free transfer of scalable laser-induced graphene for electronic skins
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68131-3This study reports a universally cryogenic stripping strategy for transferring laser-induced graphene onto diverse surfaces without modulus limitations. title: JULGI coordinates vascular development and leaf patterning through non-cell-autonomous regulation of miR165/166
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67339-7Leaf and vein development must be precisely coordinated, yet the molecular signals linking these processes have remained unclear. summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68259-2The authors present a rapid wavefront shaping system for fast, high-resolution imaging deep inside scattering tissue. summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03102-6The fraction of C4 plants in terrestrial biomass decreased from 16% to 12% between 1982 and 2016, but the change is too small to explain the observed change in the isotopic composition of atmospheric carbon dioxide, according to estimates based on a C3/C4 distribution model and a carbon cycle box model.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03095-2Thermonuclear explosions, global fallout, low-yield nuclear tests and releases from a nuclear reprocessing facility each exhibit a distinct signature in the americium isotopic ratios, serving as a fingerprint of radioactive contamination sources, according to accelerator mass spectrometry analysis of environmental samples from different contamination sources.

title: The observed September 2023 temperature jump was nearly impossible under standard anthropogenic forcing
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-026-03178-8The jump in global heat in September 2023 was unprecedented, with factors such as increased water vapour and shortwave radiation contributing to the increased heat, according to reanalysis data and climate model simulations.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 10 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03169-1In eastern Siberia, climate alone cannot explain Late Holocene wildfire dynamics, and human activity is a potential driver of shorter, multi-centennial-scale variability of wildfire since c. 5000 years BP, based on palaeoecological records and data model comparisons.

title: Amplified Arctic–boreal fire regimes from permafrost thaw feedbacks
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01894-yThe Arctic–boreal fire regime is greatly affected by biophysical and biological feedbacks from permafrost degradation, according to long-term observations of soil active layer thickness from 1997 to 2018 and causal inference modelling.

title: Overestimation of past and future increases in global river flow by Earth system models
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01897-9The magnitude of the increase in global river flow between 1980 and 2014 is 13.6% lower than Earth system models estimate and is expected to be 9.3% lower in the future, according to an analysis of emerging constraints on the components of the water cycle.

title: Hepatokine fibrinogen-like protein 1 drives liver-kidney crosstalk to promote renal fibrosis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68188-0Hepatokine FGL1 mediates liver-kidney crosstalk in renal fibrosis. Upregulated by circulating inflammatory cytokines post-injury, it binds ALK5 to potentiate TGF-β signaling and promotes fibrotic progression, presenting a promising target for CKD.

title: High yield production of 3-hydroxypropionic acid using Issatchenkia orientalis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67621-83-Hydroxypropionic acid (3HP) is a top Department of Energy value-added chemical and precursor to bioplastics, yet cost-effective microbial bioproduction remains elusive. Here the authors establish efficient 3HP production in an acid tolerant yeast and validate its financially viability.

title: Controlling the sign of optical forces using metaoptics
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67928-6The authors demonstrate deterministic control of optical forces on a metasurface integrated with a suspended silicon nanomembrane. By tailoring multipolar mode interference, they realize both attractive and repulsive forces in a phase-controlled standing wave, experimentally validated, paving the way for advanced optical manipulation in nanoscale optomechanics.

title: Timely bespoke phage-antibiotic combination to treat refractory Pseudomonas aeruginosa mediastinitis and vascular graft infection
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68136-yPhage therapy is an alternative treatment against biofilm-associated infections. In this case report, phage-antibiotic therapy was used to treat a vascular graft infection caused by a refractory fluoroquinolone non-susceptible Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

title: Magnetization generation and giant nonlinear transport at symmetry-engineered interfaces
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66149-1Symmetry breaking is key to numerous notable effects, for instance, the emergence of a Rashba interaction at interfaces between two materials. Here, Zhang, Ding, and coauthors succeed in breaking in-plane mirror symmetries via crystallographic engineering, and observe a giant non-linear Hall effect and current induced magnetization at room temperature.

title: Dictionary of human intestinal organoid responses to secreted niche factors at single cell resolution
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68247-6Here they developed an inflamed human intestinal organoid model and used it to build a scRNA-seq perturbation atlas of microenvironmental cues in the context of inflammatory bowel disease.

title: Time-resolved X-ray imaging of the current filamentation instability in solid-density plasmas
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67160-2The authors report on imaging developments of solid-density plasmas and the current filamentation instability by means of the LCLS-XFEL at SLAC. This offers insights on the instability in the solid density region, stimulating new modelling of laser-solid interactions.

title: Write cycling endurance exceeding 10<sup>10</sup> in sub-50 nm ferroelectric AlScN
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68221-2The authors demonstrate that stable partial polarization control achieves more than 1010 write cycles in ferroelectric AlScN. Further, reducing capacitor diameter increases breakdown voltage, boosting endurance.

title: Diatom lipids open window to past ocean temperatures in the polar regions
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03177-1A biomarker sea surface temperature proxy based on two isomeric diatom lipids can reconstruct a range of sea surface temperatures for both the Arctic and Antarctic Oceans, according to analyses of sea surface temperature reconstructions across polar seas

title: Optimized wetland rewetting strategies can control methane, carbon dioxide, and oxygen responses to water table fluctuations
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03163-7Observations and model work from a Danish temperate wetland during 2007-2023 indicate that the site acted as a carbon dioxide sink and a methane source, and a stable water table at about 9 cm depth can be recommended as the best rewetting solution

title: Environmental variability shapes biodiversity and protected area priorities in Canada
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03166-4Network of protected areas in Canada is not well-buffered against increasing environmental stochasticity from 1981 to 2025, suggesting decreased species richness, as revealed by daily and spatially explicit normalized difference vegetation index.

title: Creeping snow drought threatens Canada’s water supply
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03162-8While 2000-2019 Snow Water Availability increased, nearly 3% of Canada and Alaska, particularly in the North American Cordillera, underwent significant losses. Along with other insignificant losses, water supply for 86% of Canadians is threatened.

title: A sample dredged from the Alpha Ridge records evidence of an emergent volcanic setting at 90 Ma
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02981-zFresh basaltic glass preserved in a sample of volcanic breccia record a single eruptive event at the Alpha Ridge around 90 Ma, suggesting that parts of the ridge were emergent during the final stages of magmatism in the High Arctic Large Igneous Province, according to geochemical and geochronological analysis of the sample.

title: Well-connected basalt sequences as potential reservoirs for large-scale carbon sequestration revealed by strontium isotopes
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03020-787Sr/86Sr pattern of residual salts from a 100 m basalt section reveal a vertically connected pore water system unaffected by massive lava flow interiors, supporting continental margin basalt sequences as viable reservoirs for permanent CO2 storage.

title: Area based conservation tools have mixed effects across all SDGs but research may overstate effects
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03040-3Marine protected areas have both positive and negative effects across all 17 Sustainable Development Goals and are more effective as targeted interventions rather than broad policy for sustainability, based on an analysis of existing literature.

summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01900-3Global drifter data reveal that tropical cyclone-induced sea surface cooling in storm-affected areas is far weaker than indicated by estimates from microwave satellites and state-of-the-art climate models. Despite enhanced self-induced cooling driven by greenhouse warming, tropical cyclones are fuelled by a sea surface warming trend that is about twice the tropical mean warming.

title: Distinct contributions of suspended and sinking prokaryotes to mesopelagic carbon budget
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01888-wGenetic and isotopic analyses of samples from the northeast Atlantic reveal that suspended prokaryotic dark carbon fixation substantially fuels carbon inputs below the sunlit ocean, while particle-attached communities make an overlooked contribution to carbon demand.

title: Weak self-induced cooling of tropical cyclones amid fast sea surface warming
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01879-xTropical cyclones cool the ocean surface less than previously thought, indicating that current projections may underestimate their future intensity and frequency, according to an analysis of global sea surface drifters data over 1992–2021.

title: Efficient synthesis of chiral vicinal diamines with four contiguous stereocenters via sequential dynamic kinetic resolution of 2,3-diamino-1,4-diketones
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 09 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67526-6The stereoselective construction of acyclic molecules bearing three or more contiguous stereocenters remains a long-standing challenge in modern organic synthesis. Here, the authors describe an iridium-catalyzed dynamic kinetic resolution of 2,3-diamino-1,4-diketones to enable the efficient synthesis of acyclic vicinal diamines containing four contiguous stereocenters.

title: Chlorella-derived extracellular vesicle-based nanogels suppress cGAS-STING for treatment of radiation-induced lung injury
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68140-2Radiation-induced lung injury (RILI), a serious complication of radiation exposure, is associated with cGAS-STING pathway overactivation. Here, the authors developed a nanogel based on microalgal extracellular vesicles and a cGAS inhibitor to prevent and treat RILI and its progression to fibrosis.

title: Data-driven inverse design of multifunctional bicontinuous multiscale structures
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68089-2This study presents a 3D large-range, boundary-identical, and open-cell microstructure datasets for the fast data-driven inverse design of bicontinuous multiscale structures with tunable elasticity and permeability for multifunctional applications.

title: Ionic glass formers show an inverted relation between fragility and non-exponential alpha-relaxation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68124-2An empirical correlation between the fragility of glass forming liquids and the broadness of their relaxation spectrum is believed to be universal. Van Lange et al. report an inverted correlation in a class of polymeric materials, implying a special role of long-ranged ionic interactions in vitrification.

title: Bulk-cusp microstructure for controllable multi-directional liquid spreading
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68237-8The ability to control the wetting of liquids on solid surfaces is crucial for advanced science and engineering. Here, a bulk-cusp microstructure enables programmable 0–4 directional droplet spreading without external energy, driven by precursor film dynamics and capillary forces, offering potential for improved lubrication and smart cooling applications.

title: A Mechanophenotyping chip for high-throughput detection of metastatic bacteria-infected circulating tumor cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68152-yEmerging evidence underscores biophysical characteristics of cancer cells as key modulators of cancer metastasis. Here, the authors reported a single-cell mechanophenotyping chip that screens deformable CTCs to reveal the hematogenous metastatic potential of bacteria-infected breast cancer.

title: Volumetric compression regulates the phase separation of AXIN and acts as an operational amplifier to bidirectionally modulate Wnt signaling in organoids
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68209-yThe scaffold protein AXIN can promote the formation of two opposing complexes: the Wnt signalosome and a degradation complex that inhibits Wnt. Here, the authors show that mechanical compression and the presence/absence of Wnt ligand are inputs in a circuit that acts as a logic gate to control which complex is formed.

title: Constraining the effect of global change on antifungal resistance
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00756-wAntifungal resistance is a growing crisis affecting human health and agriculture that could be accelerated by global change. We call for a One Health research agenda to systematically investigate environmental drivers and inform policy to mitigate the potential of global environmental change in fuelling antifungal resistance.

title: Climate change has increased crop water consumption in Central Asia despite less water-intensive cropping
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03142-yTotal crop water consumption increased by 10% from 1987 to 2019 in Central Asia’s Amu Darya Basin, mainly driven by climate change as less water-intensive crops were adopted, according to analyses of modeled evapotranspiration from satellite imagery

title: Threshold-dependent shifts in ecosystem stability across aridity gradients on the Mongolian Plateau
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03173-5Ecosystem stability shifts at an aridity threshold where in less arid conditions it is linked to plant and fungal richness and in more arid conditions it depends on conservative plant traits and lower phylogenetic diversity, based on sampling across a 3000-km Mongolian Plateau gradient.

title: Enhanced forest management rather than afforestation has dominated China’s carbon sink over recent decades
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03176-2Forest management primarily drives the carbon sink enhancement in China from 2001 to 2021, achieving carbon gains at a rate over 4 times higher than afforestation, according to an integrated framework combining remote sensing-driven and climate-driven process models.

title: Harnessing converted phases for rapid magnitude estimation and early warning with distributed acoustic sensing offshore Chile
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03167-3Converted P-to-S seismic waves detected in fibre optic cables offshore Chile carry information on earthquake source properties, like S-waves, but arrive much faster, like P-waves, and could represent a useful tool for rapid magnitude estimation.

title: Global mapping of potential coastal compound flood risk at 0.1<sup>∘</sup> resolution
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03155-7Major river deltas and low-lying coastal regions are susceptible to compound flood risk, according to a 0.1 degree grid scale conservative global assessment that evaluates the co occurrence of riverine and oceanic flooding, integrating flood hazard, population exposure, and empirical vulnerability.

title: On the foundations of Earth foundation models
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03127-xFoundation models could transform Earth sciences, according to a synthesis which identifies 11 key characteristics to be built into the ideal foundation model and provides recommendations for effective usage of the model and standardized evaluation criteria.

title: Deep crustal hot zones control shallow magma reservoirs in an active transcrustal magmatic system
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03160-wDeep crustal melt accumulation controls the shallow melt volumes and hence the eruptive capacity of polygenetic volcanoes, according to geophysical and petrological analysis.

title: A mysterious ancient fingerprint and a lemon-shaped planet — the stories you’ve missed
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00053-6We highlight some Nature Briefing stories from the end of 2025, including: a seismic detector made from a telecom cable, and how self-heating plants attract pollinators.

title: A framework for addressing racial and related inequities in conservation
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09892-1This Perspective proposes a new framework to support the inclusion of Black, Indigenous and people of colour in conservation initiatives.

title: A hidden diversity of ceratopsian dinosaurs in Late Cretaceous Europe
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09897-wNew results indicate that rhabdodontids and the previously described Ajkaceratops are actually distinctive European ceratopsians, a group better known from Asia and North America.

title: A young progenitor for the most common planetary systems in the Galaxy
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09840-zA nine-year transit-timing campaign has measured the extremely low masses and densities of four large planets orbiting the young star V1298 Tau, which are now predicted to contract and form a typical compact super-Earth and sub-Neptune system.

title: Surface optimization governs the local design of physical networks
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09784-4Analysis of the local branching geometries of several physical networks shows violations of predictions of length and volume minimization, leading to the hypothesis that estimating the material cost requires accounting for the full three-dimensional geometry.

title: RNA-triggered Cas12a3 cleaves tRNA tails to execute bacterial immunity
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09852-9Cas12a3 nucleases constitute a distinct clade of type V CRISPR–Cas bacterial immune systems that preferentially cleave the 3′ tails of tRNAs after recognition of target RNA to induce growth arrest and block phage dissemination.

title: Plastic landmark anchoring in zebrafish compass neurons
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09888-xUsing two-photon microscopy with a panoramic virtual reality setup, how head direction cells in larval zebrafish integrate visual landmarks and optic flow to track orientation is revealed.

title: An expanded registry of candidate cis-regulatory elements
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09909-9The existing ENCODE registry of candidate human and mouse cis-regulatory elements is expanded with the addition of new ENCODE data, integrating new functional data as well as new cell and tissue types.

title: High-voltage anode-free sodium–sulfur batteries
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09867-2A new architecture based on high-valence sulfur/sulfur tetrachloride cathode chemistry is described for manufacturing high-voltage anode-free sodium–sulfur batteries, demonstrating promise for applications in grid energy storage and wearable electronics.

title: Climate change shifts the North Pacific storm track polewards
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09895-yAn observation-based storm-track proxy shows that the winter North Pacific storm track has shifted substantially polewards, suggesting regional impacts on precipitation and warming patterns, with implications for temperature variability and extreme events.

title: Prefrontal neural geometry of learned cues guides motivated behaviours
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09902-2The dorsomedial prefrontal cortex encodes the value, salience and valence of learned stimuli along distinct neural dimensions, and the geometry of these representations shapes motivated behaviours in mice.

title: Bidirectional CRISPR screens decode a GLIS3-dependent fibrotic cell circuit
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09907-xIntegrated single-cell and spatial data analysis, combined with bidirectional CRISPR screens, identify the transcription factor GLIS3 as a key driver of chronic inflammation and fibrosis and a potential marker of disease severity in patients with ulcerative colitis.

title: Soft biodegradable implants for long-distance and wide-angle sensing
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09874-3A soft, biodegradable, wireless sensing device can monitor pressure, temperature and strain over long distances (up to 16 cm), maintaining accuracy across varying positions and angles.

title: Early hominins from Morocco basal to the Homo sapiens lineage
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09914-yNew hominin fossils from the Grotte à Hominidés at Thomas Quarry I (ThI-GH) in Casablanca, Morocco, dated to around 773 thousand years ago are similar in age to Homo antecessor, yet are morphologically distinct.

title: Genetic switch between unicellularity and multicellularity in marine yeasts
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09881-4Myb1 functions as a switch-like regulator of state transitions in Hortaea werneckii, whereby its expression and degradation are coupled to nutrient conditions, stabilizing unicellular or multicellular growth.

title: Insights into DNA repeat expansions among 900,000 biobank participants
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09886-zHuman genetic variation influences instability of DNA repeats that commonly expand as we age.

title: Pulse heating and slip enhance charging of phase-change thermal batteries
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09877-0A strategy based on the design of a composite coating that enables slip-enhanced close-contact melting inside sealed phase-change thermal batteries to improve charging rates enables high-performance thermal energy storage over a wide range of temperatures.

title: Neuro-epithelial circuits promote sensory convergence and intestinal immunity
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09921-zSpecific pain-sensing nociceptors and chemosensory tuft cells form a circuit to promote type 2 immune responses in the intestine.

title: Nutrient requirements of organ-specific metastasis in breast cancer
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09898-9How the complex interplay between multiple nutrients within the microenvironment dictates potential sites of metastatic cancer growth is explored.

title: Towards fibre-like loss for photonic integration from violet to near-infrared
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09889-wGermano-silicate used as a building material for integrated photonics circuits substantially reduces optical losses, approaching levels comparable to those in optical fibres.

title: Aharonov–Bohm interference in even-denominator fractional quantum Hall states
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09891-2This study reports coherent Aharonov–Bohm interference, including statistical phase contributions, in a Fabry–Pérot interferometer at two even-denominator fractional quantum Hall states in high-mobility bilayer-graphene van der Waals heterostructures is reported.

title: Soft photonic skins with dynamic texture and colour control
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09948-2Inspired by dynamic textural modulation in cephalopod skin, polymer films whose colour and surface texture can be dynamically and independently controlled are developed and demonstrated using standard electron-beam patterning tools.

title: Mitochondrial transfer from glia to neurons protects against peripheral neuropathy
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09896-xMitochondria that are transported from satellite glial cells in dorsal root ganglia to peripheral sensory neurons through tunneling nanotube-like structures provide protection against peripheral neuropathy.

title: Intratumoural vaccination via checkpoint degradation-coupled antigen presentation
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09903-1An intratumoural vaccination chimera reprograms tumour cells into an antigen-presenting state with restored anti-tumour immunity.

title: An ancient DNA perspective on the Russian conquest of Yakutia
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09856-5Yakut communities, with Trans-Baikal admixture during the Mongol expansion, preserved genomic diversity and oral microbiomes despite the Russian conquest, which introduced cereals, pathogens and Christianity, whereas marital practices preserved low consanguinity except in one late case of traditional shamanism.

title: Mimicking opioid analgesia in cortical pain circuits
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09908-wThe anterior cingulate cortex encodes affective pain behaviours modulated by opioids; targeting opioid-sensitive neurons through a new chemogenetic gene therapy replicates the analgesic effects of morphine, providing precise chronic pain relief without affecting sensory detection.

title: Distinct neuronal populations in the human brain combine content and context
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09910-2Single-neuron recordings in humans reveal largely separate content and context neurons whose coordinated activity flexibly places memory items in context.

title: A mechanical ratchet drives unilateral cytokinesis
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09915-xDivision of embryonic cells with an incomplete contractile ring occurs by a ratchet mechanism with repeated cycles of cytoplasmic stiffening, which stabilizes the contractile actin band, and fluidization, which enables band ingression.

title: Albumin orchestrates a natural host defence mechanism against mucormycosis
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09882-3Albumin selectively inhibits Mucorales growth through the release of bound free fatty acids.

title: Small persistent humid forest clearings drive tropical forest biomass losses
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09870-7A bookkeeping approach shows that disturbed tropical humid forests experienced net aboveground carbon loss during 1990–2020, primarily driven by small but persistent deforestation clearings owing to persistent land-use conversion without forest regrowth.

title: ipRGC properties prevent light from shifting the SCN clock during daytime
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09894-zThe inability of intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells to shift the circadian clock in the suprachiasmatic nucleus during daytime is caused by light-dependent depolarization block of these cells.

title: Evidence accumulation from experience and observation in the cingulate cortex
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09885-0Humans and monkeys integrated experiential and observational evidence during a two-player task, and the anterior cingulate cortex combined the information sources into a unified neural belief representation that explains behavioural asymmetries.

title: Stress controls heterochromatin inheritance via histone H3 ubiquitylation
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09899-8A histone ubiquitin-dependent regulatory hub governs stimulus-dependent heterochromatin propagation, with important implications for understanding mechanisms governing rapid changes in the epigenetic landscape in physiology and disease.

title: Oldest known poison arrows show Stone Age humans’ technological talents
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00051-8Traces of a toxic chemical found on 60,000-year-old arrowheads hint at advanced planning by Palaeolithic hunters.

summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03988-4An in-depth analysis of nutrient availability across mouse tissues reveals their influence on the spread of cancer to other organs.

summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03983-9Measurements of the masses of exoplanets orbiting a young star have identified a system of low-density ‘super-puff’ planets.

title: Of all the quarries: Casablanca fossils reveal African ancestors of Homo sapiens
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03986-6Surprising fossil finds in a Moroccan quarry reveal 773,000-year-old hominin specimens that are close to the ancestor of modern humans.

title: Octopus-inspired ‘synthetic skin’ changes colour and texture on demand
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00052-7A material that can switch its appearance, cephalopod-style, could have future applications in robotics or display technology.

title: How viral RNAs escape a host mechanism that controls translation
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04001-8A long-standing question has been how viral RNAs that use genetic codes different from those used in human cells can still drive efficient viral protein production during infection. It emerges that the sequences of 5′ untranslated regions in viral RNAs drive codon-usage-independent translation by blocking mRNA circularization, enabling viruses to evade the host’s codon-usage control of translation.

title: Chronic pain could be eased by uncoupling the sensory and emotional experiences
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03987-5Researchers identify the neurons involved in the emotional distress associated with pain, and design a genetic approach that could soothe suffering without opioid drugs.

title: Exotic quasiparticles glimpsed in graphene
summary: Nature, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04016-1Bilayer graphene has been used to observe robust interference patterns consistent with the presence of fractionally charged quasiparticles known as non-Abelian anyons. Demonstrating and controlling this interference is a crucial step towards harnessing these elusive quasiparticles as building blocks for fault-tolerant quantum computers.

title: A way to identify the biological basis of gene–trait associations

title: Natural hazard susceptibilities and inequities reduced by short-term groundwater use
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01884-0The use of groundwater can help mitigate the impacts of natural disasters, thereby increasing the resilience of communities during and after events, according to a synthesis of hydrology and disaster response research.

title: Oligocene deep ocean oxygen isotope variations primarily driven by temperature
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01878-yLarge benthic oxygen isotope fluctuations in the Oligocene Southern Ocean primarily represent deep water temperature changes, suggesting the Antarctic ice sheet volume was relatively stable, according to a clumped isotope record.

title: Boron neutron capture therapy preserves immune cells and induces robust anti-tumour immunity in preclinical mouse model
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67984-yThe response of different immune cell subsets to radiation therapy (RT) greatly influences treatment outcome. Here, the authors compare the effects of RT and Boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) in preclinical mouse models of melanoma and colorectal cancer, and show that BNCT achieves tumor cell-selective killing while preserving immune cell functions, allowing sustained anti-tumor immunity and long-term memory.

title: Perioperative tislelizumab plus lenvatinib treatment for resectable hepatocellular carcinoma at high risk of recurrence: single-arm phase II trial
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68108-2Hepatectomy is an important part of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) treatment but postoperative recurrence limits long-term survival. Here, the authors report a phase II clinical trial investigating perioperative tislelizumab (anti-PD-1) and lenvatinib (multi tyrosine kinase inhibitor) in patients with resectable HCC with a high-risk of recurrence.

title: Dynamic microvascular monitoring with miniaturized omnidirectional broadband photoacoustic imaging system for living entities (MOBILE)
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68190-6The authors developed MOBILE, a compact photoacoustic imaging system for non-invasive hemodynamic monitoring in motion. It reveals how microcirculation adapt during exercise, offering a dynamic window into cardiovascular health.

title: Electronegativity and entropy design of layered oxides for sodium-ion batteries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68016-5The structure of layered oxides dictates their properties as positive electrodes in sodium-ion batteries, but its rational design remains challenging. Here, authors employ electronegativity and configurational entropy as a design descriptor to guide the synthesis of a sodium-deficient layered oxide with an O3 stacking sequence, rendering good thermal and air stability.

title: Longitudinal metabolome profiling from pregnancy through childhood and risk of neurodevelopmental disorders at age 10
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68115-3Metabolomic profiling of 581 mother–child pairs revealed patterns associated with neurodevelopmental disorders (NDD). Maternal metabolomic profiles at gestational week 24 showed the strongest predictive value, with quinolinate consistently associated with NDD across time points and linking maternal inflammation to NDD risk.

title: O-GlcNAcylation of AMFR stabilizes TSPAN4 to regulate migrasome formation for viral release
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68220-3Migrasomes mediate the release of cytoplasmic contents, thereby facilitating intercellular communication. Here, the authors propose a regulatory mechanism underlying migrasome biogenesis and elucidate how viruses exploit this pathway to promote cell-to-cell transmission.

title: AKAP95 condensates regulate transcription and can be targeted in MLL-fusion driven oncogenesis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68192-4The role of RNA-binding protein (RBP) phase separation in transcriptional regulation and its contribution to tumorigenesis remains to be characterised. Here, the authors show that RBP AKAP95 physically co-condenses with the mixed lineage leukemia 1 (MLL1) translocated fragment commonly found in MLL rearranged (MLLr) leukemia to promote leukemogenesis.

title: Boosted catalytic activity by metal-oxide interface in porous single-crystalline niobium oxide monoliths
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68117-1Introducing and stabilizing oxygen vacancies within oxide supports remains a significant challenge for enhancing catalytic activity in redox reactions. Here, the authors fabricate centimeter-scale porous single-crystalline Nb₂O₅ monoliths and deposit Pt clusters on their surfaces, creating an interfacial system that markedly improves catalytic CO oxidation.

title: Meta-analytic evidence identifies efficacy beliefs and social norms as key correlates of public emergency preparedness
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 08 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03151-xPublic emergency preparedness is most consistently linked to efficacy beliefs and social norms, with effects varying across populations, according to a meta-analysis synthesizing over three decades of global multi-hazard research.

title: Abundant surface resins present on Middle Devonian land plants
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03161-9Analysis of Middle Devonian plant cuticles reveals abundant surface resins, markedly pushing back the origin of plant resin production and demonstrating that these resins played a key role in early plant adaptation to terrestrial environments.

title: Coupled climate–land-use interactions modulate projected heatwave intensification across Africa
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03110-6Nonlinear climate and land-use interactions drive historical and future heatwave intensification across Africa, especially in Western South Africa, based on multivariate bias-correction and explainable AI applied to CMIP6 future projections.

title: Large carbon dioxide emissions avoidance potential in improved commercial air transport efficiency
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03069-4Air transport currently operates inefficiently, with a theoretical carbon dioxide emission reduction potential of more than 50 percent, according to an efficiency model developed using global operational data from commercial aviation.

title: Why cancer can come back years later — and how to stop it
summary: Nature, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04149-3Researchers are targeting dormant tumour cells that might explain why some cancers reappear long after successful treatment.

title: Defossilize our chemical world
summary: Nature, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00005-0Achieving net zero means eliminating fossil fuels, not carbon — the chemical element has a crucial part to play in powering the modern world.

title: Artificial skin mimics the octopus’s art of disguise
summary: Nature, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03984-8A ‘photonic skin’ with controllable colour and texture brings materials science a step closer to the adaptive camouflage found in nature.

title: Jellyfish sleep like humans — even though they don’t have brains
summary: Nature, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00044-7Studying ancient sea creatures’ snoozing habits could shed light on the origins of sleep.

title: Daily briefing: The human cells in our bodies that aren’t genetically ours
summary: Nature, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00043-8‘Microchimeric’ cells passed from your mother can challenge basic tenets of immunology. Plus, an experimental cancer vaccine that uses blood ‘cleaned’ with ultraviolet light and the evidence for trying ‘Dry January’.

title: High normal stress promoted supershear rupture during the 2023 Mw 7.8 Kahramanmaraş earthquake
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01893-zThe difference in rupture speed between fault segments in the 2023 Mw 7.8 Kahramanmaraş earthquake may be explained by the contrasting structure of and stress on these segments, according to seismic tomographic imaging of beneath the fault zone.

title: Synchronous bipolar retreat of mid-latitude ice masses during Heinrich Stadials
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01887-xGlaciers in New Zealand retreated at about the same time as mid-latitude glaciers in the Northern Hemisphere during Heinrich Stadials, indicating strong global teleconnections during the last glacial period, according to a marine sediment record.

title: Periodic ocean oxygenation events during the mid-Ediacaran
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01883-1Periodic marine oxygen oscillations occurred throughout the middle Ediacaran Gaskiers Glaciation, probably stemming from increased organic carbon burial destabilizing ocean redox systems, according to geochemical constraints and modelling.

title: Costs and benefits of halving nitrogen waste for global sustainable development goals
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01874-2Halving nitrogen waste could help meet a broad array of Sustainable Development Goals, with associated societal benefits topping US$1.3 trillion, according to an integrated assessment framework that evaluates cost-effectiveness and environmental impacts.

title: Refrigeration down to 0.16 K using a frustrated magnet Gd<sub>2</sub>B<sub>2</sub>MoO<sub>9</sub>
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68278-zUltra-low-temperature magnetic refrigeration is strongly dependent on the performances of refrigerants. Here the authors provide a frustrated magnet Gd2B2MoO9 with excellent magnetocaloric performances and a minimum temperature of 0.16 K is achieved.

title: Spontaneous chlorine production from chloride-containing brines
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68181-7Researchers report a spontaneous method that produces chlorine directly from chloride-containing brines by harnessing their inherent osmotic energy and chloride ions, without any external energy input.

title: A multidimensional workflow profiling of allogeneic virus-specific T cell therapies reveals potency-linked signatures
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67924-wAllogeneic T cell therapies could be used in therapeutic applications because of their potential for ‘off-the-shelf’ access and standardised production. Here the authors have developed a multidimensional workflow profiling platform for EBV-specific T cell therapy and show that correlative biomarkers of T cell potency and effector function are associated with therapeutic effectiveness in xenogeneic mouse EBV-LCL models.

title: Long-distance spin transport in frustrated hyperkagome magnet Gd<sub>3</sub>Ga<sub>5</sub>O<sub>12</sub>
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68203-4Spin transport properties of magnetically ordered materials have been well studied. Here, the authors report an anomalous spin signal exhibiting spin transport over 480 microns in the frustrated hyperkagome magnetic insulator Gd3Ga5O12.

title: DNA actively regulates the “safety-belt” dynamics of condensin during loop extrusion
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 07 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68239-6The molecular mechanism underlying DNA entrapment during loop extrusion by condensin remains poorly understood. Here, the authors use multiscale molecular simulations to show that DNA itself steers a flexible “safety belt” in condensin.

title: Impact of GC content on de novo gene birth
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68022-7Noncoding DNA can generate microproteins, some of which evolve into new genes. This study finds that de novo genes preferentially originate from GC-rich, foldable sequences, showing how base composition influences the birth of new proteins.

title: Reconfigurable all-solid-state topological lasing at arbitrary sites
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68173-7Topological lasers usually emit light from a fixed spot. Here, authors report on an all-solid-state platform where topological lasing is demonstrated at trivial lattice terminations as well as at reconfigurable arbitrary sites. The device consists of a Su-Schrieffer-Heeger waveguide array, printed in a disordered Nd:BaLaGa₃O₇ crystal.

title: NTAC: Neuronal type assignment from connectivity
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68044-1In this study, the authors develop NTAC, Neuronal Type Assignment from Connectivity, using synaptic connectivity alone to identify cell types with high accuracy within minutes on a standard CPU.

title: Improved European heat event simulation in eddy-resolving climate models
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03145-9High-resolution climate models simulate a more realistic relationship between North Atlantic sea surface temperatures and European summer temperature extremes, because of the reduced surface temperature bias in the subpolar North Atlantic.

title: High-resolution planet Dove data identify local drivers of kelp canopy persistence
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03134-yHigh-resolution kelp canopy maps from a convolutional neural network showed that kelp persistence after a marine heatwave was linked to pre-heatwave persistence, cooler sea surface temperatures, shallow habitats that are often missed by coarser satellite sensors, and lower levels of fragmentation.

title: Patterns in solar activity over the first millennium CE
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03120-4Findings on solar activity in the first millennium CE confirm four Grand Solar Minima and indicate two patterns of weakening-then-strengthening in the Schwabe cycle, providing insights into solar dynamo behavior, according to analysis of Δ14C data from tree rings.

title: Regional responses to oceanic variability constrain global drought synchrony
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03111-5Large-scale synchronized droughts affect 1.84–6.5% of global land mass, and although warming amplifies this synchrony, precipitation variability and oceanic forcing limit its global extent, according to a study that analyzed 120 years of global drought data.

title: Strong mismatch in climate change adaptation between intentions of private forest owners in Canada and institutional support
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02942-6Private forest owners in Canada can better adapt to climate change through locally relevant information and technical assistance, as shown by a comprehensive survey and Bayesian analysis.

title: High H<sub>2</sub> production in sediment-hosted hydrothermal fluids at an ultraslow spreading mid-ocean ridge
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02962-2Hydrothermal systems at ultraslow-spreading mid-ocean ridges are still not well understood, especially where vent fluids interact with sediments and ultramafic rocks. In this study, we present geochemical data from vent fluids collected in 2024 at the Jøtul hydrothermal field on the northern Knipovich Ridge. We analyzed major elements, dissolved gases, and used thermodynamic modeling to study how the fluids react with surrounding rocks. The fluids contain extremely high levels of CH4, even higher than those in the Guaymas Basin, and show features typical of sediment-hosted hydrothermal systems, suggesting that organic matter in clastic sediments has been broken down by the hot fluids. In contrast, the fluids also have high H2 ( > 15 mM) and low H2S concentrations, which are common in vents hosted by ultramafic rocks and geological evidence suggests that the vent field sits on a detachment fault. Our thermodynamic modeling indicates that the high H2/H2S ratios could be explained by the breakdown of organic matter at around 400 °C, rather than by reactions with ultramafic rocks. These findings broaden our understanding of sediment-hosted vent systems and suggest that fluid-sediment interaction is a more important source of oceanic carbon and dissolved hydrogen than previously recognized.

title: These women helped to shape quantum mechanics — it’s time to recognize them
summary: Nature, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04151-9An astute book redresses our collective perception of a field that became known as ‘boys’ physics’.

title: The geomorphic scar of fire
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01890-2Post-fire soil erosion is a widespread global phenomenon with geomorphological consequences. Quantifying its impacts provides insights to inform and strengthen soil conservation efforts.

title: Canadian net forest CO<sub>2</sub> uptake enhanced by heat drought via reduced respiration
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01875-1The extreme hot and dry conditions of 2023 reduced soil respiration and enhanced net forest carbon sequestration in Canada, offsetting wildfire emissions, according to satellite-based and in situ observations of CO2 fluxes.

title: Deglaciation of the Prudhoe Dome in northwestern Greenland in response to Holocene warming
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01889-9The ~500-metre-thick Prudhoe Dome in northwestern Greenland completely deglaciated 7,000 years ago, highlighting the sensitivity of the ice sheet to mid-Holocene warming, according to luminescence and geochemical data from sub-ice sediments and ice cores.

title: Global estimation of post-fire soil erosion
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01876-0Global post-fire soil erosion accounts for approximately 8.1 ± 0.72 Pg per year, or 19%, of total global soil erosion, and Africa is the most impacted continent given its larger burned area, according to a global assessment of soil erosion produced by wildfires over the last 18 years.

title: Author Correction: Leishmania RNA virus exacerbates Leishmaniasis by subverting innate immunity via TLR3-mediated NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67433-wAuthor Correction: Leishmania RNA virus exacerbates Leishmaniasis by subverting innate immunity via TLR3-mediated NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition

title: Low-noise optomechanical single phonon-photon conversion for quantum networks
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67956-2Optomechanical crystals are promising building blocks for quantum networks but suffer from thermal mechanical noise. Here the authors demonstrate on-demand conversion of single phonons into high-purity telecom photons with low thermal noise and MHz-scale narrow bandwidth using a quasi-2D optomechanical system.

title: Palladium-catalyzed asymmetric migratory diarylation of unactivated directing-group-free internal alkenes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68006-7Enantioselective dicarbofunctionalization of alkenes is a powerful strategy for constructing functionalized sp³-rich molecules. Here, the authors report a palladium-catalyzed asymmetric migratory process that enables highly selective 1,3- and 1,4- diarylation of unactivated trisubstituted alkenes.

title: Deep learning and superoscillatory speckles empowered multimode fiber probe for in situ nano-displacement detection and micro-imaging
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67942-8This work introduces an in-situ nano-displacement measurement system via a multimode fiber probe with superoscillatory speckles and deep learning. It achieves 10 nm resolution and 99.95% accuracy for wafers, non-contact sensing in confined spaces.

title: Harnessing strengthening-metastability synergy for extreme work hardening in additively manufactured titanium alloys
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67683-8A new AM titanium alloy design tailors the metastability-strengthening synergy and achieves high yield strength with enhanced work hardening and ductility by leveraging a complete, sequential martensitic transformation pathway.

title: Measuring and locating the changes in protein structure using MELO
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68110-8Subtle variation can reshape protein structure but are hard to identify. Here, authors present MELO, which measures and locates structural changes, outperforms existing tools, and uncovers over 10,000 previously missed protein structure change pairs.

title: Neoadjuvant immune checkpoint blockade before chemoradiation for cervical squamous carcinoma (GINECO window-of-opportunity COLIBRI study): a phase II trial
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67646-zPre-treatment dual immune checkpoint blockade in cervical cancer remains understudied. In this trial, the authors show that neoadjuvant immune checkpoint blockade enhances immune activation and correlates with improved response to subsequent chemoradiation in patients with cervical carcinoma.

title: Homogeneous crystallization via sustained solvent-extraction channels for methylammonium-free all-perovskite tandem solar cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68213-2Despite high efficiencies, all-perovskite tandem solar cells are hindered by thermal instability. Guo et al. address this issue by introducing a multi-Lewis-base modulator, which suppresses the formation of dense Cs-rich films in Pb-Sn perovskites to concurrently deliver high performance and stability.

title: Changing the heatwave visual discourse in the news media
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 06 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00754-yNature Reviews Earth & Environment interviewed Professor Saffron O’Neill about their project investigating the visual communication of heatwaves in the news media.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03152-wLong-term monitoring reveals that rising sodium concentrations in a large One Water drinking water supply arise from road salts, reclaimed water, and treatment chemicals, highlighting freshwater salinization as a socio-ecological-technological challenge.

title: Intensified annual cycle of tropical Atlantic sea surface temperature regulates Pacific cooling
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03168-2Recent observed cooling in the Pacific Ocean is driven by an intensified annual cycle of sea surface temperature in the tropical Atlantic altering the distribution of seasonal precipitation, according to analyses of idealized experiments and climate model simulations.

summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 05 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02977-9Compound drought-heatwave events exhibit two distinct regimes, with land-driven regimes being more predictable than atmosphere-driven ones, based on analyses of extreme events in the past decades.

title: WRN structural flexibility showcased through fragment-based lead discovery of inhibitors
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66768-8In this study, authors employ fragment-based lead discovery to identify WRN inhibitors. title: Structural barriers control the spatial extent of slow earthquake slip
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68179-1This study shows that slow earthquake slip in the Nankai Trough is confined by structural barriers, including fault geometry, material contrasts, and subducted ridges, revealing key controls on the potential extent of future megathrust ruptures.

title: Crystallization modulation for wide-bandgap perovskites with universal defect passivation toward efficient perovskite/organic tandem photovoltaics
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68125-1Defect formation and phase instability remain critical challenges for perovskite/organic tandem solar cells. Jiang et al. address this by designing an additive to modulate the crystallization thermodynamics of wide-bandgap perovskite, achieving a record efficiency of 22.1% in a flexible cell.

title: Non-remnant triglyceride-rich lipoproteins due to lipoprotein lipase deficiency increase atherosclerosis in mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68193-3Elevated triglyceride-rich lipoproteins (TRLs), long linked to cardiovascular disease, were thought to be harmful mainly in their remnant form. Here, the authors show that intact TRLs, not just their remnants, promote atherosclerosis and vascular inflammation in a mouse model.

title: A chromosome region linked to neurodevelopmental disorders influences locomotor behavior through sex-specific neural circuits
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68047-yThis study demonstrates that 16p11.2 hemideletion, a genetic deletion linked to neurodevelopmental disorders, affects male and female mice differently, altering specific striatal neuronal circuits and driving sex-specific behavioral changes.

title: Distinct antidepressant therapies act on a common brain network
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67945-5This study demonstrated that distinct antidepressant therapies act on a common brain network. title: Detection and identification of vacancy defects in antimony selenide
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68153-xAntimony selenide is a promising photovoltaic material, but the presence of point defects degrades performance. Here, the authors use positron annihilation spectroscopy combined with theory to detect and identify vacancy-type point defects.

title: A nose-to-brain axis for spoiled food odor-triggered defensive responses in male mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68057-wRancid odors trigger retching and aversion. Here, authors show a nose-to-brain axis whereby such odors activate olfactory-piriform circuits that diverge to mediodorsal thalamic nucleus and nucleus accumbens to mediate retching-like behavior and aversion.

title: From the lens of early-career researchers: bridging science, technology, arts, and humanities to tackle antimicrobial resistance
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67863-6Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global challenge. In this Perspective, authors highlight the unique role of early-career researchers (ECRs) in the transdisciplinary progress in AMR research.

title: The SoftFoot Pro: an anthropomorphic and adaptive soft articulated prosthetic foot
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68194-2Irregular terrains challenge users of classic prosthetic feet. title: Peptide-functionalized membrane camouflage for endogenous H<sub>2</sub>S-induced photothermal immunotherapy of orthotopic colorectal cancer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 03 January 2026; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65876-9Colorectal cancer has high recurrence and metastasis rates making treatment difficult. Here, the authors report on peptide modified cell membrane coated cobalt based metal-organic frameworks which degrades and forms, in situ, photothermal materials with H2S, allowing for immune-photothermal therapy.
