title: Earth’s composition: Origin, energy budget, and insights from geoneutrinos
summary: Publication date: Available online 31 December 2025Source: Geochimica et Cosmochimica ActaAuthor(s): William F. McDonough
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta

title: A chiral fermionic valve driven by quantum geometry
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09864-5Fermionic currents of opposing chirality can be spatially filtered without the need for a magnetic field using the quantum geometry of topological bands in single-crystal PdGa.

title: Random heteropolymers as enzyme mimics
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09860-9Modulation of random heteropolymers results in globular polymer clusters with catalytic activity mimicking proteins.

title: Quantifying the global eco-footprint of wearable healthcare electronics
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09819-wAn integrated systems engineering framework based on life-cycle inventories is used to quantify the global eco-footprint of wearable healthcare electronics and identify effective mitigation strategies.

title: Some of your cells are not genetically yours — what can they tell us about life and death?
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04102-4A tiny population of cells that are passed across the placenta between mother and baby challenge basic tenets of human immunology.

title: Economic inequality does not equate to poor well-being or mental health
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03833-8A meta-analysis of 168 studies covering more than 11 million people found no reliable link between economic inequality and well-being or mental health. In other words, living in a place that has large gaps between the rich and poor does not affect these outcomes, with implications for policy.

title: How to reduce the environmental impact of wearable health-care devices
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03982-wA model quantifies the environmental footprint of wearable health-care electronics and identifies strategies to reduce their environmental toll.

title: Sub-Saharan Africa has lost almost one-quarter of its pre-industrial biodiversity
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04007-2To map the biodiversity of sub-Saharan Africa, 200 specialists in African plants and animals were asked to estimate local species abundances. This approach integrates contextual, place-based knowledge into a multi-scale, comparative biodiversity assessment that can be used to support policy decisions at national, regional and global scales.

title: Highly efficient LED device built by stacking layers of light-emitting perovskite
summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04021-4Stacking light-generating layers in ‘tandem’ light-emitting diodes (LEDs) can enhance performance, but achieving efficient and stable tandem LEDs made with perovskite materials has remained a challenge. A tandem perovskite-based device that seems to benefit from ‘recycling’ of photons between stacked layers demonstrates highly efficient performance, surpassing the combined emissions of two single-unit devices.

title: Sideways lipid presentation by the antigen-presenting molecule CD1c
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67732-2Despite extensive structural studies elucidating how antigens are anchored to antigen-presenting molecules and presented to T cells, little is known about the display mechanism of the lipid-antigen-presenting molecule CD1c. Here, by combining structural immunology, lipidomics, and biophysical analysis, the authors reveal that the CD1c binding cleft accommodates two different lipids, one of them with a bulky headgroup positioned sideways for display to T cells, rather than upwards, different from the conventional upright antigen-presentation mode

title: EatA mediated degradation of intestinal mucus is species-specific and driven by MUC2 structural features
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68037-0In this work, authors show how the enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC) protease EatA cleaves the human mucus protein MUC2 at a C-terminal site, allowing bacteria to cross the intestinal mucus, reach epithelial cells, and promote infection, as demonstrated using a human MUC2 transgenic mouse model.

title: BARCODE: high throughput screening and analysis of soft active materials
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67963-3BARCODE is an open-access software that automates high throughput screening of microscopy video data to produce a unique fingerprint or ‘barcode’ of performance metrics that enables optimization and accelerates discovery of soft, active materials.

title: Domain oriented universal machine learning potential enables fast exploration of chemical space of battery electrolytes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67982-0Efficient modeling of battery electrolytes is limited by the accuracy-cost trade-off. Here, authors develop a universal machine learning potential to accurately calculate transport and solvation properties across a broad chemical space.

title: SigmaR1 is an auxiliary translocon factor with lipid-binding activity that regulates protein and lipid droplet homeostasis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68157-7This study identifies the ER sheet protein SigmaR1 as an auxiliary translocon factor. By directly binding phosphatidylcholine and specific translocon components, SigmaR1 maintains protein and lipid homeostasis; its loss triggers lipid droplet accumulation in hepatic cells.

title: Structured liquid-based reconfigurable all-liquid optical fibers
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67954-4Reconfigurable all-liquid optical fibers enable gigabit-speed communication while offering softness, rapid self-healing, and on-demand reconfiguration, providing a resilient alternative to brittle quartz fibers in dynamic application environments.

title: Generating crossmodal gene expression from cancer histopathology improves multimodal AI predictions
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66961-9Multimodal fusion of digital pathology and transcriptomics can improve cancer diagnosis, but remains impractical in clinical settings. Here, the authors develop a crossmodal generative model, PathGen, to synthesise transcriptomic data from histopathology slides, and show how the combination of these multimodal data improves cancer diagnosis and prognosis prediction.

title: Distinct diet-microbiome associations in autism spectrum disorder
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67711-7Here, the authors identify distinct, autism-specific diet microbiome interactions, showing how unhealthy diets and synthetic emulsifiers drive dysbiosis. The findings pave the way for microbiome-aware dietary strategies for autism.

title: Warming and resource enhancement shape food webs in South China Sea coral reef system
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03147-7Environmental gradients in temperature and productivity jointly, yet asymmetrically, shape the structure and resilience of coral reef food webs, according to analysis of environmental DNA data from the South China Sea.

title: China’s supply chain digitalization reduces urban pollutants and carbon dioxide emissions locally
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03139-7Supply chain digitalization reduces urban air pollutants and carbon dioxide emissions by up to 9 percent locally but increases them by 4 percent in nearby areas, according to an analysis that uses a quasi-natural experiment and a difference-in-differences method

title: Signatures of widespread Surtseyan volcanism at the northern Reykjanes ridge
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03128-wEffusive volcanism dominates at water depths of 300 m or greater while phreatomagmatic Surtseyan eruptions become prevalent at shallower depths, according to analyses of high-resolution seismic reflection profiles, multibeam bathymetry, and seafloor imagery.

title: Can boomerangs bounce?
summary: Nature, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03989-3Privacy in the age of computers and a Nature reader questions eyewitness accounts of boomerangs in our weekly dip into the archive.

title: Safe as houses
summary: Nature, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04026-zConstructive feedback.

title: Science in 2050: the future breakthroughs that will shape our world — and beyond
summary: Nature, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04100-6Nuclear fusion. People on Mars. Artificial general intelligence. These are just some of the advances that could come by the mid-century mark.

title: Mummies give up their secrets — but not their mystery
summary: Nature, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04103-3A challenging exhibition asks why we are so fascinated with the preserved bodies of our ancestors, and how we should treat them.

title: Put pressure on publishers to follow best practice — external regulation is the answer
summary: Nature, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04099-wJournals that work hard to meet the needs of both authors and readers should be acknowledged publicly — encouraging others to follow suit.

title: Flexible computation of object motion and depth based on viewing geometry inferred from optic flow
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67857-4People typically perceive the motion and depth of objects correctly even during walking or running, when visual inputs change markedly. The authors show that this accurate perception is achieved by inferring the observer’s viewing geometry from optic flow.

title: Rhomboid protease GlpG regulates type 1 pili quality control and virulence in pathogenic E. coli
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67697-2The disruption of the rhomboid protease gene glpG in E. coli leads to defects in bacterial colonization. Here, the authors show that GlpG is essential for the assembly of type 1 pili, a virulence factor required for colonization of bacteria in eukaryotic cells.

title: Magnetic memory driven by spin splitting torque in nonrelativistic collinear antiferromagnet
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68065-wAltermagnets combine spin-split electronic bands with zero net magnetization, making them ideal for integration into spin-based information processing devices. Here Guo, Chen, Zeng, and coauthors demonstrate a magnetic memory making use of the altermagnetic spin splitting torque in a three terminal MRAM device.

title: Capsaicin diet drives gut inflammation and exosomal miR-17-3p elevation in idiopathic short stature
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67883-2The authors demonstrate that plasma exosomes from children with idiopathic short stature contain elevated hsa-miR-17-3p, that disrupts growth signaling and impairs cartilage cell proliferation. A capsaicin-rich diet in rats triggered gut inflammation, increased exosomal miR-17-3p and recapitulated features of idiopathic short stature.

title: Structure of the G<sub>q</sub>-coupled adhesion receptor ADGRL4
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67629-0ADGRL4 is a cancer-implicated adhesion GPCR whose ability to couple to G proteins had been unclear. Here, authors show that ADGRL4 weakly engages Gq and determine its 3.1 Å active-state structure, revealing its mechanism of activation.

title: Topological exciton-polaritons with negative coupling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68025-4Negative coupling is an intriguing mechanism for linking lattice sites, enabling phenomena unattainable with positive coupling alone. Here, the authors introduce this unique coupling into the polariton system and demonstrate topological polariton condensation in lattices with negative coupling.

title: Autonomous biogenesis of all thirty proteins of the Escherichia coli translation machinery
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67772-8The cell-free biogenesis of the protein translation machinery is essential for the creation of a self-regenerating synthetic cell. Here the authors synthesise all 30 E. coli translation proteins in a cell-free system and demonstrate functionality.

title: bZIP factors of the Unfolded Protein Response interact with PIF4 to promote thermomorphogenesis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67909-9UPR-derived bZIP factors interact with PIF4 to boost plant growth at moderately elevated temperatures, linking ER stress signaling with temperature-responsive pathways.

title: Atmospheric rivers as mediators between climate teleconnections and burned area variability in North America
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03124-0The interactions between atmospheric rivers and large-scale climate teleconnections modulate the timing and magnitude of vegetation and fire responses across North America, according to remote sensing, teleconnection index, and reanalysis data analyses.

title: Minor effects of nutrient additions on soil microbial carbon use efficiency
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03096-1Microbial carbon use efficiency remains largely unaffected by nutrient additions, regardless of the overall amount or the specific type of nutrient applied, according to a global meta-analysis of 427 observations.

title: Perennial redox potential dynamics in Alaskan degraded and non-degraded permafrost soils
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03143-xRedox potential pattern in the permafrost soil active layer showed large seasonal differences, with reducing conditions in the summer and autumn, and oxidizing conditions in winter and spring, according to three years of soil redox potential measurements, at three sites near Fairbanks, Alaska.

title: Precision irrigation framework could enhance water productivity and reduce carbon emissions in China
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03137-9Increased irrigation water productivity, crop yields stabilization, mitigation of energy consumption and carbon emissions are possible using a high-resolution water-food energy-carbon optimization framework that integrates multi-source datasets and future crop distribution scenarios.

title: Species diversity advances autumn senescence via enhanced belowground carbon allocation in semi-arid grasslands
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 30 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03109-zEnhanced species diversity promotes the allocation of resources to belowground biomass, accelerates seasonal carbon cycle, thereby reducing aboveground resource availability triggering earlier senescence, according to field observations from Northern China coupled with global remote sensing data.

title: Audio long read: Will blockbuster obesity drugs revolutionize addiction treatment?
summary: Nature, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04147-5Researchers are investigating whether GLP-1 drugs can help blunt cravings for nicotine, alcohol and opioids.

title: Probing pollutants: how I use penguin faeces to measure contaminants in Antarctica
summary: Nature, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04105-1Buse Tuğba Zaman is developing a way to track tiny amounts of contaminants — and fulfilled a dream to visit Earth’s most remote continent.

title: Why academics should do more consulting — and how to make it work
summary: Nature, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04104-2Encouraging academics to act as advisers to outside organizations is the most effective way to serve society’s needs.

title: Let 2026 be the year the world comes together for AI safety
summary: Nature, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04106-0AI technologies need to be safe and transparent. There are few, if any, benefits from being outside efforts to achieve this.

title: Nine books to help shape your science career in 2026
summary: Nature, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04101-5If you’ve hatched a New Year plan to move abroad, improve your presentations or chase happiness as a 20-something researcher, you’ll find advice aplenty in these books.

title: Contrasting trends in very large hail events and related economic losses across the globe
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01868-0The frequency of very large hail events between 1950 and 2023 increased most in Europe and decreased most in South America because of variations in atmospheric humidity and instability, according to a statistical model analysis.

title: Optical heterostructure in a two-dimensional organic crystal
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67937-5Optical heterostructures have potential in integrated photonics and optoelectronics but are challenging to prepare in single-component systems. Here, the authors report an intrinsic optical heterostructure in an organic nanosheet, with enhanced fluorescence in an inner zone.

title: Multi-omics analysis identifies a microbiota–bile acid–TLR signaling axis driving bladder injury in interstitial cystitis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68060-1Through integrated multi-omics and experimental validation, this study reveals that altered gut microbiota and bile acid metabolism activate TLR3 to induce urothelial injury in interstitial cystitis, identifying a pathway with therapeutic potential.

title: Polyamide nanofilms with Janus microporous framework for sustainable solvent filtration
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68049-wTuning permselectivity and chemical stability is desirable for polymer membranes, though it is challenging to balance these properties. Here the authors report a polyamide membrane using modified interfacial polymerization methods for stable and highly permeable organic solvent nanofiltration.

title: Multi-omic relay velocity modeling uncovers dynamic chromatin-transcription regulation across cell states
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67259-6Cell fate transitions rely on dynamic regulatory programs that RNA velocity often blurs. Here, the authors show that MoFlow integrates multi-omic data to infer locally adaptive, single-cell-resolved velocities that illuminate fine-scale regulatory dynamics.

title: Plasma protein profiling predicts cancer in patients with non-specific symptoms
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67688-3Cancer detection is challenging, especially in patients with diffuse symptoms that overlap with non-malignant conditions. Here, the authors develop a proteomics- and minimally invasive blood sampling-based classification model as a triage tool to identify and prioritize individuals at high cancer risk that would benefit the most from rapid and highly sensitive diagnostic modalities.

title: Fusion of multi-source precipitation records via coordinate-based generative models
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67987-9This study presents PRIMER, a coordinate-based diffusion model, that fuses multiple imperfect precipitation records into a unified prior, enabling Bayesian inference like downscaling, bias correction, and data assimilation.

title: Molecular characterisation of the Bacillus subtilis SpbK antiphage defence system
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67810-5SpbK protects Bacillus subtilis from phage infection by depleting NAD⁺. In this study, the authors uncover the molecular mechanisms underlying SpbK’s self association-dependent NADase activity and its activation by the SPβ phage portal protein YonE.

title: Viral entry shapes HCMV latency establishment
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68063-yHCMV infection can become productive or latent. Here the authors show that variations in the number of incoming viral particles across cell types is a key factor of this decision, identifying entry efficiency as a key regulator of latency.

title: Precipitation, moderated by spring temperature and vegetation, drives runoff efficiency in the Upper Colorado River Basin, USA
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 29 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03136-wStatistical causal inference shows that runoff efficiency in the Upper Colorado River Basin rises with higher precipitation and snow, accompanied by cooler springs and suppressed vegetation, and falls when precipitation and snow are lower and accompanied by warmer springs and enhanced vegetation.

authors:

title: Photocontrolled trimethoprim PROTACs targeting the eDHFR protein tag
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67527-5In this work authors demonstrate how photocontrolled tag-targeted degradation enables precise, spatiotemporal control of protein expression in tumor cells and CAR T cells, offering an esapproach for regulating engineered proteins with light.

title: Printable polymer nanocomposites for scalable and architected radiative cooling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67831-0Daytime radiative cooling materials typically require high filler loading or porosity. Here, authors introduce rheology–optics coupling to control particle dispersion, enabling printable low-filler PDMS–ZrO₂ composites for scalable and durable radiative coolers with versatile architectures.

title: Shock compression of FeOOH and implications for iron-water interactions in super-earth magma oceans
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67845-8Laser shock experiments on an iron-water phase reveal its density, melting, and electronic changes under extreme pressures. The results suggest dense deep magma oceans and show that iron-water reactions can greatly shrink and densify super-Earths.

title: General variation in the Fusarium wilt rhizosphere microbiome
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67760-yThis study reveals how tomato plants recruit specific bacteria to combat Fusarium wilt. A key bacterium is identified to thrive on root-derived compounds and suppress the fungal pathogen, offering insights into plant-microbe defense alliances.

title: FGF7 promotes load-bearing tendon regeneration and suppresses fibrosis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67355-7Growth factor signalling has been shown to alleviate tissue fibrosis and promote repair. Here, the authors use fibroblast growth factor 7 (FGF7) knockout mice and an FGF7-loaded hydrogel to show that this factor can promote functional regeneration of tendon.

title: Coupling nitrate electrochemical reduction and nitrite oxidation of ethanol for acetamide synthesis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68096-3Conventional amides electrosynthesis methods confine reactions to solely electrochemical reduction or oxidation processes, resulting in low amides yield rates. Here, the authors report a tandem electrolyzer that couples cathodic nitrate reduction with anodic ethanol oxidation to produce acetamide.

title: Highly efficient heterogeneous thermal catalysis for noble-metal-free hydrogen production from formic acid
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67895-yFinding efficient ways to release hydrogen from liquid carriers is key to advancing clean energy systems. This study introduces a resilient catalyst that drives highly selective hydrogen production from formic acid using low-grade heat.

title: Surface halogenation engineering for reversible silicon-based solid-state batteries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67985-xSilicon negative electrodes in solid-state batteries exhibit poor reversibility. Here, the authors demonstrate surface halogenation engineering that suppresses irreversible lithium loss, achieving 94.3% initial Coulombic efficiency and 72% capacity retention over 500 cycles at 25°C.

title: Small vegetation biomass retention efficiency across global forests
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03138-8Only 0.2–2.6% of synthesized biomass stays in live plants at the global scale, as revealed by biomass retention efficiency, a newly developed metric based on satellite data and ecosystem models.

title: The hurricane-induced decay of mesoscale eddies: an energy source for near-inertial waves
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 27 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03113-3Mesoscale eddies’ decay is accompanied by subsurface near-inertial wave generation, indicating direct energy transfer, according to remote sensing and in situ measurements.

title: Photochromism of pyridine-substituted merocyanine through reversible C-N bond formation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67626-3Spiropyran and merocyanine systems are useful due to the photoswitching properties, but do have some limitations. Here, the authors report pyridine-substituted merocyanines as photochromic compounds, with a photoinitiated C-N bond formation.

title: Size-dependent translocation of polystyrene nanoplastics across biological barriers in mammals
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67876-1Previous studies on biodistribution of microplastics showed discrepancies. This study provides quantitative data to date on how nanoplastics distribute and eliminate from the body using carbon-14-radiolabelled particles in rats.

title: SREBP1-mediated lipogenesis promotes dedifferentiation and senescence of vascular smooth muscle cells through epigenetic remodeling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67534-6Microgravity triggers carotid artery aging via SREBP1. This lipid regulator remodels chromatin by boosting acetyl-CoA, silencing contractile genes while activating aging pathways. Targeting SREBP1 blocks senescence, revealing a therapeutic strategy for spaceflight-associated vascular remodeling.

title: Continental outflow shapes the circum-Antarctic pattern of summertime atmospheric mercury depletion zones
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67864-5Air flowing out from the Antarctic continent largely determines where summer atmospheric mercury depletion events (AMDEs) occur around Antarctica, making them most common in areas where Antarctic cold, downslope winds meet.

title: Designer RNA nanostructures co-transcribed and self-assembled inside human cell nuclei
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67817-yThe use of nucleic acid-based nanostructures as synthetic biological tools remains challenging. Here they present synthetic RNA structures that fold and self-assemble inside human cell nuclei, offering a platform for imaging, sensing, and future therapeutic applications.

title: Modulation of inter-hemispheric temperature gradients on the Holocene Asian-Australian summer monsoon
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67951-7The reconstructed Holocene Australian summer monsoon in this study, together with the Asian monsoon records, show that the coupling evolution of Holocene Asian-Australian monsoon was dominated by the thermal imbalance between two hemispheres.

title: Gut microbiota-derived metabolite isovalerylcarnitine modulates salt sensitivity of blood pressure and incident hypertension: a multicenter dietary salt intervention trial
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67513-xHere, combining data from a clinical trial and animal models, the authors show a role for a gut-acylcarnitine axis in the development of salt-sensitive hypertension, and identify isovalerylcarnitine as a key microbiota-derived modulator and potential target for the precision prevention of hypertension.

title: In-sensor analog optoelectronic processing of concurrent event and memory signals for dynamic vision sensing
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68013-8High-efficient dynamic vision requires capturing instantaneous motion and its temporal evolution to infer trajectories, velocities, and even predict future motion. Kim et al. introduce an analog event-memory sensor that is capable of event detection and temporal integration. The proposed architecture can reduce latency, power consumption, and circuit complexity compared to conventional dynamic vision sensors.

title: Identifying conservation priorities in global Biodiversity Hotspots to protect small-ranged vertebrates from agricultural pressure
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03099-yCroplands in biodiversity hotspots expand rapidly from 2000 to 2019 at a rate above the global average, and more than half of conservation gaps are found within the hotspots, as revealed by site-level observations and satellite data.

title: Anthropogenic fingerprints in global synchronization networks of high aerosol pollution events
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03141-zLong-term trends in aerosol pollution events are dominated by anthropogenic forcing, increasing asynchronization between near-field transmission and wider teleconnections, according to analysis of extreme aerosol pollution event synchronization.

title: Northward rupture and early afterslip of two graben-bounding normal faults during the 2025 Dingri earthquake of Tibet
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 26 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03132-0A wedge-shaped graben extension mechanism for the 2025 Dingri earthquake involved two graben-bounding faults, highlighting that early postseismic deformation is mainly driven by shallow afterslip and viscoelastic relaxation, with the afterslip spatially complementing coseismic slip, according to integration of field observations, geodetic and seismic data.

title: Strain rate concentration along the Niigata-Kobe tectonic zone, central Japan as explained by 2D collision numerical models with visco-elasto-plastic rheology
summary: Publication date: 15 February 2026Source: Earth and Planetary Science Letters, Volume 676Author(s): Erika J. Moreno, Shoichi Yoshioka, Vlad C. Manea, Marina Manea, Nobuaki Suenaga
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Earth and Planetary Science Letters

title: Machine learning-assisted kinetic matching model for rational electrode design in aqueous zinc-ion batteries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67996-8Aqueous zinc-ion batteries are safe and affordable but limited by incompatible electrode kinetics. Here, authors present a machine learning framework that resolves this mismatch, enabling the rational design of durable and stretchable zinc-ion batteries.

title: Engineered vesicles enhance oral antibiotic absorption in proximal small intestine and mitigate gut dysbiosis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68082-9In this work, authors present a biohybrid delivery system aimed at overcoming low oral bioavailability and antibiotic-induced dysbiosis by enabling efficient antibiotic transport in the proximal small intestine.

title: Ultrasensitive multi-degree-of-freedom piezoionic sensor via synergistic hydrogel-ion interactions
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67613-8Piezoionic flex-sensors are limited by sensitivity and unidirectional bending response. Here, the authors achieve a high piezoionic flex-sensitivity by tuning hydrogel-ion interactions, and decoupling of multi-degree-of-freedom bending via a square prism-shaped fiber structure.

title: mGluR4–NPDC1 complex mediates α-synuclein fibril-induced neurodegeneration
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67731-3How α-synuclein interacts with the neuronal cell surface to contribute to disease pathology is not fully understood. Here, the authors conducted a comprehensive search for neuronal membrane proteins mediating α-synuclein aggregate uptake, and identified mGluR4 and NPDC1 as essential for Parkinson’s disease related neurodegeneration triggered by extracellular α-synuclein fibrils.

title: Calcium channel blockers increase the risk of aortic aneurysm and dissection
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-68086-5Aortic aneurysm and dissection are lethal vascular diseases lacking effective medical therapy. Here the authors show that calcium channel blocker use increases AAD risk, worsens disease progression in models and patients, and may impair post-repair outcomes, warranting caution in at-risk hypertension.

title: Germline epigenome editing identifies H3K9me3 as a mediator of intergenerational DNA methylation recovery in mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67488-9The authors develop a system to erase DNA methylation at H19-DMR in mouse sperm. Despite loss, methylation partly recovers via H3K9me3 after fertilization, revealing partial intergenerational epigenetic inheritance.

title: Multi-scale classification decodes the complexity of the human E3 ligome
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 25 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67450-9The authors of this study map the human E3 ubiquitin ligome using a metric learning approach, revealing a unified classification framework that explains preserved patterns and functional segregation of E3 families, linking enzymes to substrates and drug interactions, and guiding strategies for targeted therapies.

title: Carbon dynamics control contemporary mercury burial in Arctic Ocean sediments
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03058-7Mercury concentrations in sediments of the North American Arctic Margin and the Arctic Ocean basins can be entirely explained by carbon sources and cycling, according to analysis of sediment cores from the polar ocean.

title: A market-based insurance approach aligns environmental and economic outcomes in maize nitrogen management
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03008-3A market-based nitrogen insurance lets maize farmers cut excess fertilizer use without profit risk, as shown in simulations across 4,270 Illinois fields over 30 years and 33 nitrogen rates.

title: The Nature Podcast highlights of 2025
summary: Nature, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03756-4The team select some of their favourite stories from the past 12 months.

title: Strength in numbers: how multimerization drives HpHb uptake by CD163 scavenging receptor
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67812-3CD163 is a macrophage scavenger receptor central to the clearance of haptoglobin-hemoglobin (HpHb) complexes and the resolution of inflammation. In a remarkable example of near-simultaneous scientific progress, three complementary studies published in Nature Communications1–3 have resolved the near-atomic resolution structure of the full extracellular domain of human CD163 complexed with HpHb, primarily utilizing cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM). The most significant and unified conclusion emerging from this trio of papers is that CD163’s scavenging activity is fundamentally dependent on its ability to form functional multimers.

title: Momentum space AC Josephson effect and intervalley coherence in multilayer graphene
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67838-7The authors propose that when an intervalley coherent (IVC) state is subjected to a static magnetic field, it develops an oscillating orbital magnetization at microwave frequency, an effect analogous to a Josephson oscillation in momentum space. The effect could provide an experimental diagnostic for identifying the IVC state.

title: Directional flows using capillary assembly of photo-deformable colloidal particles at water-air interfaces
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67739-9Colloidal particles experience capillary interactions at liquid interfaces, but modifying these interactions is challenging as shape change is required. Here, the authors report polymer particles that change shape with polarised light, and therefore create flow patterns with unusual paths.

title: Subpolar North Atlantic decadal cooling may have aggravated recent Eastern Siberian wildfires
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66520-2This study shows that the recent escalation of wildfires in Eastern Siberia is primarily driven by a decline in fire-season precipitation, which is likely partially linked to concurrent unforced decadal cooling in the subpolar North Atlantic.

title: Vaccine-preventable HPV burden and cervical abnormalities in women during 2022–2024 Octobre Rose campaigns in Libreville
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67777-3Analyzing HPV prevalence among 1,524 women in Gabon, the authors show that most cervical abnormalities in Gabonese women are linked to vaccine-preventable HPV types, supporting the introduction of Gardasil-9 ® and strengthened HPV screening to reduce cervical cancer in Gabon.

title: Effectiveness of the 2024–2025 KP.2 COVID-19 vaccines in the United States during long-term follow-up
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67796-0Vaccinations against the SARS-CoV-2 KP.2 variant were introduced for the 2024-25 season in the United States. Here, the authors investigate the effectiveness of these vaccines up to April 2025 through a target trial emulation study using electronic health record data.

title: A stationary phase-specific bacterial green light sensor for enhancing metabolite production
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67829-8Genetically encoded sensors are generally optimized to function during exponential growth rather than stationary phase, which limits their potential value for metabolic engineering and bioproduction. Here, authors engineer a stationary phase green light sensor and use pulsatile light to optimize production of industrially relevant small molecules.

title: Demonstrating quantum error mitigation on logical qubits
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67768-4Quantum error mitigation refers to techniques that reduce, rather than correct, errors in quantum computing. Here the authors demonstrate zero-noise extrapolation applied to quantum error correction circuits on superconducting processors, effectively reducing logical errors and advancing early fault-tolerant quantum computing.

title: Author Correction: Rolling back human pluripotent stem cells to an eight-cell embryo-like stage
summary: Nature, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10044-8Author Correction: Rolling back human pluripotent stem cells to an eight-cell embryo-like stage

title: Seeding opportunities for Black atmospheric scientists
summary: Nature, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04068-3Vernon Morris inspires change in the geoscience community by calling on colleagues to commit to anti-racism in their scientific endeavours.

title: GPR4 promotes immune exclusion in colon cancer through LOXL2-mediated extracellular matrix remodeling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 24 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67967-zThe detailed mechanism of how hypoxia and acidity promote immune exclusion remains unclear. The authors here identify that GPR4, a proton sensor, induces immune exclusion by facilitating collagen alignment via upregulating LOXL2. Furthermore, inhibiting LOXL2 or GPR4 signal pathway alleviates immune exclusion.

title: Pomeranchuk instability from electronic correlations in CsTi<sub>3</sub>Bi<sub>5</sub> kagome metal
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67037-4The origin of the nematic state in the kagome metal CsTi3Bi5 remains unclear. Here, using polarization-dependent angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy and ab initio based field theoretical methods, the authors propose a d-wave nematic order driven by electronic correlations via an orbital-selective mechanism.

title: Single-cell RNA sequencing reveals a quiescence-senescence continuum and distinct senotypes following chemotherapy
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66836-zQuiescent and senescent cells often arise side by side after stress, yet their molecular relationship remains unclear. Here, the authors combine live-cell imaging and single-cell RNA sequencing to reveal a continuum of cell-cycle withdrawal.

title: A brain-to-small intestine circuit mediates morphine-induced constipation in male mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67765-7Neural mechanisms mediating opioid-induced constipation are not fully understood. Here authors find that morphine-induced constipation is mediated by a neural circuit from the paraventricular nucleus of hypothalamus to the dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus, and subsequently to the small intestine in male mice.

title: Magnetically controlled microrobotic system for programmable stiffness tuning and active steering of microcatheters
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67638-zSurgical tasks within tortuous and narrow lumens require interventional instruments with controllable mechanical adaptability. Here, the authors present the Helixoft microrobotic system, which enables continuous stiffness tuning and active steering of microcatheters with diameters down to 300 μm controlled by weak magnetic fields.

title: Mitigating urban‒rural disparities in humid-heat risks in China
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67558-yThis study shows that the rapid advancement of China’s urban sustainable development process has significantly reduced urban vulnerability, narrowing the gap in comprehensive humid-heat risk between urban and rural areas.

title: Intrinsic light reflection of conjugated films towards high-performance organic solar cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67379-zThe intrinsic light reflection of organic conjugated films significantly influences the optical performance of devices through Fabry–Pérot micro-cavity effect. Here, authors modulate cell micro cavity via tuning materials’ refractive index to improve photovoltaic performance of organic solar cells.

title: The benefits of exploring a large scenario space for future energy systems
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67593-9Seemingly unproblematic method choices can substantially affect the results of energy systems analyses. Frey et al. show robust results for affordability, supply security, and sustainability from 11,000 scenarios while varying these method choices.

title: Nitrogen deposition alleviates phosphorus-induced imbalances in soil enzyme stoichiometry
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03115-1Phosphorus addition alone reduces phosphorus-acquiring enzyme activities by 14%, while phosphorus combined with nitrogen addition boosts nitrogen-acquiring enzyme activities by 21%, according to a meta-analysis based on 155 field studies across various ecosystems.

title: Ultimate soil nitrogen microbial function evolution pathway fixation–comammox–nitrate reduction in long–term arid
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03085-4In the drier loess soil, Gammaproteobacteria possess symbiotic nitrogen-fixing genes that promote microbial structural and functional succession over the ten-thousand-year scale and support a nitrogen fixation-comammox-nitrate reduction cycle, according to analysis of samples in Luochuan, China.

title: Diverse crop rotations offset yield-scaled nitrogen losses via denitrification
authors: Marcel G. A. van der Heijden
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 23 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03116-0Increased crop diversity in rotations reduces nitrogen losses relative to crop yield, making it an effective practice for sustainable farming, based on an analysis of 106 cereal fields across Europe and 56 climatic, soil, microbial, and management variables.

title: Non-equilibrium snapshots of ligand efficacy at the μ-opioid receptor
summary: Nature, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10056-4Non-equilibrium snapshots of ligand efficacy at the μ-opioid receptor

title: Daily briefing: Explore 2025 with Leif Penguinson
summary: Nature, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04120-2Can you spot the penguin in every game this year?

title: More intermittent mid-latitude precipitation accompanied extreme early Palaeogene warmth
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01870-6Mid-latitude precipitation became less frequent but more intense through the early Palaeogene, reflecting a global hydroclimate response to extreme warming, according to a global multi-proxy reconstruction of precipitation characteristics.

title: Flexible monolithic 3D complementary circuits based on 2D semiconductor inks
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66419-y2D semiconductors hold promise for the fabrication of high-density flexible integrated circuits, but they often require high-temperature processing or transfer steps. Here, the authors report the low-temperature ( ≤ 150 °C) fabrication of wafer-scale 3Dintegrated flexible complementary circuits based on 2D semiconductor inks.

title: Structural insights into toxicant export mediated by ABCC2 in Arabidopsis thaliana
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67713-5Here, the authors present the structures of Arabidopsis ABCC2, a detoxification transporter mediating the export of toxicants. A dimeric architecture is revealed and multiple transport states are captured, shedding lights on its working mechanism.

title: Maintenance of cytoplasmic and membrane densities shapes cellular geometry in Escherichia coli
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67553-3Chure et al. analyse experimental data to show that E. coli bacteria maintain stable protein density ratios between cytoplasm and membranes. In addition, they develop a biophysical model that predicts surface-to-volume ratio from ribosomal content and protein partitioning across cell compartments.

title: Trends in vertical wind velocity variability reveal cloud microphysical feedback
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67541-7This study shows that long-term climate change systematically alters small-scale wind variability and its vertical velocity, influencing cloud microphysics and the Earth’s radiative balance.

title: Unconventional high-harmonic generation in resonant membrane metasurfaces
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67871-6High-harmonic generation from metasurfaces is believed to follow conventional power laws with integer exponents. In this work, authors discover that the strong local fields related to a metasurface high-Q resonances can modify the effective nonlinear response and enable the generation of high harmonics following non-integer-power laws.

title: Computational design of allulose-responsive biosensor toolbox for auto-inducible protein expression and CRISPRi mediated dynamic metabolic regulation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67669-6Transcription-factor biosensors enable programmable metabolism. Here, the authors integrate structure and computation for mechanism-guided iterative redesign of the allulose biosensor PsiR, increasing sensitivity and dynamic range, enabling allulose-triggered expression system and CRISPRi circuit.

title: A binary self-amplifying expression platform enabling lipid nanoparticle-free vaccines and nanomedicines
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66252-3The authors present Gemini, their bifunctional replicon platform capable of functioning as either self-amplifying RNA (saRNA) or self-amplifying DNA (saDNA).

title: Li-F polarity-driven stabilization of −VII oxidation state of gold at high pressure
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67973-1The stabilization of an unconventional −VII oxidation state of gold is demonstrated in Li10AuF under high pressure. This electride phase features paired interstitial anionic electrons, expanding our understanding of charge distribution.

title: Author Correction: Hot springs reflect the flooding of slab-derived water as a trigger of earthquakes
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03107-1Author Correction: Hot springs reflect the flooding of slab-derived water as a trigger of earthquakes

title: An improved model of particle attenuation reduces estimates of Southern Ocean carbon transfer efficiency
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03090-7Modelling the water column as two distinct depth regimes captures particle attenuation in the Southern Ocean, reducing particulate organic carbon flux into the mesopelagic, according to particle attenuation modelling combined with Argo float data.

title: Evidence for landslides triggered by impact events on Ceres
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03119-xEvidence suggests that meteoroid impacts on Ceres can trigger landslides, according to morphometric and absolute dating analysis of landslides and impact craters.

title: Tropical Indian Ocean forcing on North American terrestrial and agricultural productivity decline under greenhouse warming
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03126-yWarming in the tropical Indian Ocean triggers stationary Rossby waves that create a high-pressure ridge over western North America, cutting off moisture transport and reducing precipitation, soil moisture, and crop yields, based on observational datasets, reanalysis products, and climate models.

title: Spatial heterogeneity of the Holocene winter temperature in mid-latitude Asia
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03117-zA warm early Holocene in the east contrasts with a warmer middle-late Holocene in central mid-latitude Asia, linked to heat redistribution and the importance of ocean-atmosphere interactions in shaping temperature patterns during this period, according to analysis of four lakes records in mid-latitude Asia.

title: Enhanced tropical cyclone precipitation variability is linked to Pacific Decadal Oscillation since the 1940s
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 22 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03129-9Latewood width records from southeast China show that increased tropical cyclone precipitation variability is linked to stronger Pacific Decadal Oscillation variability since the 1940s, indicating tree-ring dynamics as a new proxy for Pacific Rim climate risk.

title: Mechanosensitive dynamics of lysosomes along microtubules regulate leader cell emergence during collective cell migration
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67645-0During collective migration, only a few cells become leaders that guide tissue movement. Here, the authors show that contractile forces drive lysosomes to the cell edge, where they activate Rac1 and trigger leader cell emergence.

title: Eye movements during free viewing to maximize scene understanding
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67673-wPeople often look around without a specific task in mind (free viewing). Here, the authors demonstrate that free viewing eye movements aim to understand scenes by frequently focusing on people and objects that maximize scene comprehension.

title: Overlooked deforestation from global mining activities in the 21st century
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67501-1The study provides a comprehensive inventory of global mining footprints, finding that mining causes higher deforestation than previously estimated, with half linked to unrecorded activities, and highlighting the underestimated environmental impacts.

title: Antibiotic use and survival from breast cancer: A population-based cohort study in England and Wales
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67800-7Studies in mouse models have suggested a link between antibiotic use and breast cancer but epidemiological evidence in human populations is inconsistent. Here, the authors use linked electronic health records from England and Wales to investigate the association between oral antibiotic use and survival in women with breast cancer.

title: Electrochemical dechlorination and hydrocarbon valorization by cobalt phthalocyanine with non-proton-coupled redox property
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67720-6Electrochemical dechlorination provides a sustainable method to treat chlorinated volatile organic compounds polluted water and produce value-added hydrocarbon. Here, the authors report cobalt phthalocyanine grafted on sulfur-doped graphene for efficient CH2Cl2 dechlorination at moderate potentials.

title: Volatile and non-volatile pathogen cues shape host extracellular vesicles production in pre-infection response
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67789-zExtracellular vesicles are central to immune regulation and stress responses. Here, the authors show how pathogen-derived compounds regulate host EV production showcasing new insight into how animals anticipate and prepare themselves for infection.

title: Risk of major adverse cardiovascular events with aripiprazole versus olanzapine, quetiapine, and risperidone in severe mental illness: a target trial emulation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67843-wInitiating aripiprazole antipsychotic monotherapy versus olanzapine, quetiapine or risperidone might reduce cardiovascular event risk in severe mental illness. Here, the authors show patients initiating aripiprazole had similar 5-year risk as the comparators, but risk was higher in those continuing risperidone versus aripiprazole

title: Neoadjuvant serplulimab combined with chemotherapy for resectable oesophageal squamous cell carcinoma: a single-arm, phase 2 trial
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67589-5Oesophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is the most common form of oesophageal cancer, often diagnosed late. This group presents a phase 2 trial reporting efficacy and safety of neoadjuvant serplulimab plus chemotherapy in locally advanced ESCC, and showing distinct tumour microenvironment profiles.

title: Large gains in leaf scale photosynthetic rates of sparsely vegetated arid and semi-arid lands
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03121-3Vegetation in arid regions benefits from higher leaf-scale assimilation rates and expanded leaf area, boosting carbon uptake, while productive forests and croplands experience declines due to increased shading and climate stress, based on remote sensing data and multiple process-based models.

title: Ecological restoration reverses terrestrial water storage losses in the Mu Us Sandyland in China
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 21 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03101-7Ecological restoration in China’s Mu Us Sandyland reverses decades of water loss, indicating early depletion followed by recovery after 2011, with climate-driven gains up to 351% projected by 2100, as revealed by satellite, hydrological modelling, and machine learning analyses.

title: Emergence of mammalian-adaptive PB2 mutations enhances polymerase activity and pathogenicity of cattle-derived H5N1 influenza A virus
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67753-xAvian influenza A H5N1 has recently caused infections in humans following spillover events into cattle. Here, the authors investigate the genetic basis for the expanded host range of the virus.

title: Scoping review of artificial intelligence via mobile technology and social media for health in Africa
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64766-4There are many opportunities to combine mobile technologies and social media with Artificial Intelligence to improve health in Africa. Here, the authors conduct a scoping review on such tools and make recommendations to enhance their contribution in advancing health in Africa.

title: Lithium-ion battery recycling through an integrated electro-membrane crystallization technology
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67678-5This study presents a scalable and sustainable electro-membrane crystallization-assisted general recycling technology that efficiently recovers high-purity lithium, manganese, nickel, and cobalt from spent lithium-ion batteries.

title: Zinc-oligoether carboxylate salts as electrolyte additives for aqueous Zn metal batteries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67435-8Aqueous zinc batteries suffer from hydrogen evolution and dendrite growth during zinc plating. Here, authors report zinc oligoether salts as electrolyte additives to promote the formation of passivation layer on Zn metallic electrode and extend the lifetime of aqueous Zn-based batteries.

title: Mapping risks of health conditions in people with atopic eczema in English primary care and hospital data
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67247-wA study using English electronic health records from millions of people with atopic eczema provides an evidence resource covering the full spectrum of associated comorbidity, providing a big picture overview as well as results for each individual outcome.

title: Insights into the self-assembly and interaction of sars-cov-2 fusion peptides with biomimetic plasma membranes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67640-5This study shows how SARS-CoV-2 fusion peptides assemble and reshape membranes, revealing cooperative mechanisms that lower barriers to viral entry and offering principles for designing antiviral and membrane-responsive nanomaterials.

title: Trait-like visual cortical hyperactivity in trait anxiety
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67480-3Here, the authors show people with high trait anxiety display stable, parvocellular-specific visual cortical hyperactivity linked to disrupted cortical excitation–inhibition modulation. Trait anxiety thus alters sensory encoding from the earliest stages of cortical processing.

title: Chromosome-level haplotype-resolved assembly of highly heterozygous grass genomes with PhaseGrass
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66377-5Current methods to generate haplotype-resolved assemblies for highly heterozygous genomes suffer from reference bias or may generate imbalanced haplomes. Here, the authors present the PhaseGrass workflow and demonstrate its application in assembling highly heterozygous genomes of Lolium perenne and L. multiflorum.

title: Riverine emission of small plastic particles from Yangtze River into the ocean
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 20 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03106-2In the Yangtze River, microplastic abundance decreased with increasing water depth, and the central channel exhibited lower microplastic abundance compared to the left and right channels, according to field monitoring of plastic particle fluxes.

title: Leveraging peri-urban forests to reduce temperature and air pollution-related urban mortality in European cities
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03079-2Across European cities, peri-urban green areas can reduce mortality from non-optimal temperatures and, to a lesser extent, air pollution, with effectiveness depending on tree species and meteorological conditions, according to a coupled climate-chemistry model and tree planting scenarios.

title: Mediterranean precipitation variability is driven by complex atmospheric mechanisms beyond the North Atlantic Oscillation
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03104-4Precipitation variability over Italy is shaped mainly by Mediterranean climate patterns rather than Atlantic influences, which underscores the role of Mediterranean cyclogenesis in regional rainfall dynamics, according to deep learning, teleconnection, and back-trajectory analyses.

title: SPLiCR-seq: A CRISPR-Based Screening Platform for RNA splicing Identifies Novel Regulators of IRE1α-XBP1 Signaling Under ER Stress
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67633-4Systematic investigation of RNA splicing regulation remains challenging. Here, authors present SPLiCR-seq, a CRISPR platform enabling direct measurement of splicing outcomes for pooled perturbations. They identify GADD34 as a novel IRE1α-XBP1 regulator, with inhibition enhancing CAR-T cell activity.

title: Directed evolution of a TNA polymerase identifies independent paths to fidelity and catalysis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67652-1Engineering polymerases to synthesize alternative genetic polymers remains a challenging problem in synthetic biology. The current study offers insights into the structural and biochemical changes responsible for improving the fidelity and catalytic activity of a laboratory evolved TNA polymerase.

title: Quantum electrodynamics of photonic time crystals
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67572-0Photonic time crystals (PTCs) have unveiled unusual band structures and phenomena due to temporal modulation of optical properties. Here, the authors address non-Hermitian features of PTCs within a purely Hermitian Hamiltonian description, bridging classical and quantum approaches.

title: Peptidyl-tRNA hydrolase 2 is a negative regulator of peripartum cardiomyopathy with heart failure in female mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67852-9Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a potentially fatal heart condition with poorly understood molecular causes. Here, the authors show that loss of the protein PTRH2 in female mice leads to postpartum heart failure, identifying it as a potential therapeutic target.

title: Combined models of violent conflict and natural hazards improve predictions of household mobility in Bangladesh
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03086-3In Bangladesh, exposure to violence or natural disasters increases mobility, and households with remittances are more likely to move, according to machine-learning analysis.

title: China’s carbon neutrality agenda unmasks a persistent north-south divide in toxic pollutant reduction
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03084-5China’s polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons emissions will peak around 2027, then decrease by 2060, and regional disparities in emissions per gross domestic product are likely to persist, according to analysis that uses energy consumption and emissions data and machine learning.

title: Detection of energetic equivalence depends on food web architecture and estimators of energy use
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 19 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67615-6The universality of the energetic equivalence rule has long been debated. Here, the authors show that across 183 soil invertebrate food webs, size–density and energy use varied with trophic level, energy measure, and food web structure, showing that ecosystem energetics depend on context and trophic complexity.

title: Author Correction: Exploring the space of self-reproducing ribozymes using generative models
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67592-wAuthor Correction: Exploring the space of self-reproducing ribozymes using generative models

title: Author Correction: A guidance to intelligent metamaterials and metamaterials intelligence
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67597-5Author Correction: A guidance to intelligent metamaterials and metamaterials intelligence

title: Genetic and dietary determinants of gut microbiome-bile acid interactions in the BXD genetic reference population
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67680-xThe authors show that genetic and dietary factors reshape the microbiome and influence gut microbiome–bile acid crosstalk. They also identify potential modulators and offer insights into microbiome–host communication.

title: Molecular mechanisms of receptor recognition and antibody neutralization of coxsackievirus A6
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67666-9This study defines a two-receptor entry mechanism for coxsackievirus A6: heparan sulfate for initial attachment and KRM1 for uncoating. Protective antibodies that block KRM1 binding were identified, offering a path for therapeutic development.

title: Lactate mitochondrial oxidation drives stemness potential in metastatic breast cancer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67091-yMetastatic cancer cells rely on metabolic flexibility to survive. Here, the authors show that metastatic breast cancer cells use lactate for mitochondrial oxidation via the CD147/MCT1/LDHB complex to sustain stemness and promote metastasis.

title: Large-area and soft magnetoelastic sensing for normal and shear stress distribution toward pressure injury prevention
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67146-0Pressure injuries (PI) are prevalent clinical complications arising from excessive normal and shear stresses. Here, the authors present a skin-interface tri-axial stress sensing system to offer full-area coverage for PI prevention and quantitatively optimize intraoperative skin-interface stress.

title: Structural insights into cationic amino acid transport and viral receptor engagement by CAT1
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67704-6CAT1 is a transporter involved in amino acid metabolism and a receptor for Friend murine leukemia virus (FrMLV). This study presents the cryo-EM structure of the mCAT1/frRBD complex, revealing how mCAT1’s structure determines viral tropism and host specificity.

title: Large increases in maize residue carbon inputs in the US Corn Belt from 1980 to 2020
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03078-3Maize residue carbon inputs in the US Corn Belt increased by 46% from 1980 to 2020, worth $14.7 billion in today’s carbon markets, but challenging the progress of conservation practices, based on field experiments combined with public surveys.

title: Recognizing First Nations' values in natural capital accounting benefits all
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02693-4Including First Nations’ cultural and ecological values in natural capital accounting by engaging with land and sea managers helps bridge the gap between Indigenous and Western knowledge and enables inclusive decision making, as discussed through three Australian case studies in this Perspective.

title: Climate-driven transition in microbial deterioration and protection of stone surfaces at cultural heritage sites
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02993-9Microbial biofilm effects in cultural heritage sites shift from deterioration to protection regulated by climate-driven variations in functional genes, according to the temperate-to-tropical climate transition, according to genomic data from 10 stone cultural heritage sites in East and South Asia.

title: The source processes affect the initial chalcophile element fertility of arc magmas
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02984-wIn West Junggar, China, the unique genesis of oceanic slab-derived adakites explains their distinct platinum-group element and copper patterns relative to typical arc magmas, according to isotopic and trace elemental analyses.

title: Enhanced nitrification in higher pH soils moderates ammonia emissions in global croplands
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02997-5Higher soil pH promotes rapid ammonia oxidation through enhanced nitrification, thereby reducing substrate availability for ammonia volatilization that finally leads to reduced ammonia emission, according to an analysis of 1792 field measurements across global croplands.

title: Carbon dioxide emissions from global land cover mapping are projected to increase by 2050
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02990-yThe global land cover mapping contributes to carbon dioxide emissions projected to increase by 2050, and strategies exist to reduce emissions by 35 percent, according to an analysis that uses a process-based estimation model integrated with large-scale literature and mapping data.

title: Deciphering mantle, tectonic and climatic drivers of exhumation
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03005-6The unroofing of Central Asia over the last 230 Myr was driven by subduction dynamics along the Tethyan margin, according to a workflow for deciphering mantle, tectonic and climatic drivers of exhumation.

title: Environmentally adjusted δ13C thresholds for accurate detection of C4 plant consumption in Europe
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03031-4European-wide C₃ grain δ¹³C baseline enables adjusted δ¹³C thresholds for C₄ consumption at site and ecozone scales, to account for ecological variations of human and animal diet, according to analysis of 4,000 δ¹³C values from archaeological charred C₃ and C₄ grains.
