title: Mazdutide versus placebo in Chinese adults with type 2 diabetes
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10026-wMazdutide versus placebo in Chinese adults with type 2 diabetes

title: Author Correction: Neuroimmune cardiovascular interfaces control atherosclerosis
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-10043-9Author Correction: Neuroimmune cardiovascular interfaces control atherosclerosis

title: How the Romans built their empire of concrete
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04080-7A unique archaeological site at Pompeii, Italy, reveals the secrets of peculiarly durable Roman building materials.

title: Genes don’t explain what made humans different
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04079-0Tiny genetic variations between humans, Neanderthals and Denisovans might not be all they were cracked up to be.

title: Is bird flu the next pandemic? The science so far
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03777-zKey mutations and animal spread could raise the risk to humans.

title: Transient hepatic reconstitution of trophic factors enhances aged immunity
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09873-4Using lipid nanoparticle delivery of mRNAs to the liver in aged mice, T cell function and declining immune cues can be restored.

title: Gene-specific selective sweeps are pervasive across human gut microbiomes
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09798-yDevelopment and application of the integrated linkage disequilibrium score (iLDS) reveals both selective pressures impacting the human gut microbiome and the mechanisms by which gut bacteria adapt to meet them.

title: GTP release-selective agonists prolong opioid analgesic efficacy
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09880-5Mu opioid receptor agonists with a preference for the non-GTP-bound state of the G protein promote GTP release, thereby potentiating antinociceptive effects of drugs such as morphine and fentanyl without also increasing their respiratory or cardiac effects.

title: Programmable 200 GOPS Hopfield-inspired photonic Ising machine
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09838-7An architecture inspired by Hopfield networks based on a programmable, stable, room-temperature optoelectronic oscillator-based photonics Ising machine is introduced that can be used to efficiently address optimization and combinatorics problems.

title: An integrated view of the structure and function of the human 4D nucleome
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09890-3The 4D Nucleome Project demonstrates the use of genomic assays and computational methods to measure genome folding and then predict genomic structure from DNA sequence, facilitating the discovery of potential effects of genetic variants, including variants associated with disease, on genome structure and function.

title: Palaeometabolomes yield biological and ecological profiles at early human sites
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09843-wMetabolic and proteomic profiles derived from fossilized skeletal remains of animals enable inferences regarding physiological health and disease as well as diet to provide reconstructions of ancient soil, vegetation and palaeoclimate characteristics.

title: Astrocyte CCN1 stabilizes neural circuits in the adult brain
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09770-wNeural circuits in adult mouse visual cortex are stabilized by astrocytes, which secrete CCN1, resulting in reduced plasticity and increased maturation of multiple cell types.

title: An 11-qubit atom processor in silicon
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09827-wAn 11-qubit atom processor comprising two precision-placed nuclear spin registers of phosphorus in silicon is shown to achieve state-of-the-art Bell-state fidelities of up to 99.5%.

title: The global hydrogen budget
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09806-1Trends in global H2 sources and sinks are analysed from 1990 to 2020, and a comprehensive budget for the decade 2010–2020 is presented.

title: Visualizing interaction-driven restructuring of quantum Hall edge states
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09858-3Scanning tunnelling microscopy is used to image pristine electrostatically defined quantum Hall edge states in graphene with high spatial resolution and demonstrate their interaction-driven restructuring.

title: Prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease pathology in the community
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09841-yThe prevalence of Alzheimer’s disease neuropathological changes is reported based on blood-based biomarkers in a Norwegian population-based cohort.

title: Titan’s strong tidal dissipation precludes a subsurface ocean
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09818-xReanalysis of radiometric data from Cassini indicates that Titan does not contain a subsurface ocean, as strong tidal dissipation observed in its gravity field is not consistent with the presence of a liquid layer.

title: Human assembloids recapitulate periportal liver tissue in vitro
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09884-1Hepatocyte organoids derived directly from human tissue enable long-term hepatocyte expansion and can be combined with portal mesenchyme and cholangiocyte organoids to form a donor-specific periportal liver assembloid system.

title: Spatiotemporal cellular map of the developing human reproductive tract
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09875-2A detailed spatiotemporal roadmap of the human female and male reproductive tracts during key periods of sexual differentiation provides new cellular and molecular insights into how early axial gradients lead to specific cell lineages and tissue structures.

title: Lesion-remote astrocytes govern microglia-mediated white matter repair
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09887-yAfter spinal cord injury, lesion-remote astrocytes acquire heterogeneous, spatially restricted reactivity states that shape neuroinflammation, neural repair and neurological recovery.

title: Laser spectroscopy and CP-violation sensitivity of actinium monofluoride
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09814-1Gas-phase actinium monofluoride (AcF) has been produced and spectroscopically studied at the CERN-ISOLDE radioactive ion beam facility; the results highlight the potential of 227AcF for exceptionally sensitive searches of CP violation.

title: 3D nanolithography with metalens arrays and spatially adaptive illumination
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09842-xA three-dimensional (3D) nanofabrication platform based on metalens-generated focal spot arrays is introduced to parallelize two-photon lithography beyond centimetre-scale write field areas, revealing the potential of 3D nanolithography towards wafer-scale production.

title: The hidden cost of video-call glitches
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03820-zVideo-call glitches might seem harmless, but they can reduce people’s chances of getting hired, closing a business deal or following a doctor’s recommendation. Human brains expect video calls to feel like in-person conversations. When glitches break that illusion, it feels unsettling and strange, harming judgements of trustworthiness, likeability and credibility.

title: Stopping the next flu pandemic
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03613-4Avian influenza is devastating poultry operations, spreading in dairy cattle and infecting farm workers. Why isn’t the United States doing more to stop it?

title: Beauty is in the eye of the beholder
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04024-1The colour of regret.

title: Seven feel-good science stories to restore your faith in 2025
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03505-7Immense progress in gene-editing, drug discovery and conservation are just some of the reasons to be cheerful about 2025.

title: Mechanism for water formation on rocky exoplanets demonstrated in the lab
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04015-2Experiments have revealed that the interaction between a hydrogen-rich atmosphere and a molten planet leads to high levels of water production. Through this process, planets could be enriched with water during their formation, altering their chemistry, evolution and, possibly, habitability.

title: Virology’s most wanted: the influenza virus
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03607-2The death toll and economic damage associated with flu highlight its role as one of the most harmful viruses in history.

title: MIT fusion-lab head shot dead: a horror 'impossible to believe'
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04135-9Plasma physicist Nuno Loureiro was helping to develop clean-energy fusion devices.

title: Flu’s link to cardiovascular disease shows why vaccination is essential
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03598-0Influenza isn’t just a respiratory disease. Measures to stop its transmission, such as vaccination, could prevent thousands of heart-attack deaths.

title: Could tracking animals’ health help to avert the next pandemic?
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03602-7Avian influenza is sweeping the globe and infecting dozens of species. Advocates of an approach called One Health are calling for broad surveillance of wildlife, livestock and pets.

title: How common is Alzheimer’s? Blood-test study holds surprises
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04133-xA survey of Alzheimer’s disease prevalence in Norway confirms earlier estimates and may show how education level relates to risk.

title: Take the News & Views end-of-year quiz: vampire fungus, migratory moths and a 160-year-old mystery
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04119-9Try these 12 questions to test your knowledge of News & Views and Research Briefing articles published in 2025.

title: The Nature Podcast festive spectacular 2025
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04140-yMemorable science-themed gifts, games, seasonal songs, and Nature’s 10.

title: The quest to hatch a bird-flu vaccine
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03612-5Although development of a jab for the H5N1 strain of avian flu is well under way, other strains are receiving less attention — and political obstacles to research could hamper progress.

title: A modular quantum processor made using phosphorus atoms in silicon
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04044-xA high-performance silicon-based quantum processor has been developed in which the spins of nine phosphorus nuclei — divided into two groups, or registers — and two shared electrons act as quantum bits (qubits). The modular design of this 11-qubit processor opens the door to a scalable approach to building large, reliable quantum-computing processors.

title: A universal flu vaccine has proved challenging — could it finally be possible?
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03608-1Scientists are deploying an array of technologies that are making a vaccine against all varieties of influenza seem more achievable.

title: Systematic maps reveal how human chromosomes are organized
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03808-9Our genomes are highly structured, which facilitates gene regulation. An ambitious project has catalogued the organization of DNA in the nuclei of human cells.

title: Restoring youth to old immune cells: mRNA therapy turns back the clock
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04082-5Testing in mice suggests that rejuvenating T cells could make vaccines and some cancer therapies more effective.

title: Trump team plans to break up ‘global mothership’ of climate science
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04134-wMuch of the National Center for Atmospheric Research’s non-climate portfolio will be dispersed, the White House says.

title: Annual flu vaccines are far from ideal — this is why
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03599-zFlu-jab efficacy is often unimpressive. Improvements could come through nasal delivery.

title: Immunological sin: how a person’s earliest flu infections dictate life-long immunity
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03606-3Researchers are striving to understand the impact a phenomenon known as original antigenic sin has on immunity to the virus.

title: Operando X-ray imaging reveals size-dependent evolution of cobalt oxide thermochemical material during thermal redox cycles
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66174-0Using operando synchrotron X-ray imaging, the study reveals 3D morphological and chemical changes of thermochemical particles during redox cycles, uncovering degradation mechanisms and insights for improved thermal energy materials.

title: Spatial correlation at the boson peak frequency in amorphous materials
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67574-yPhotonic time crystals (PTCs) have unveiled unusual band structures and phenomena due to temporal modulation of optical properties. Here, the authors address non-Hermitian features of PTCs within a purely Hermitian Hamiltonian description, bridging classical and quantum approaches.

title: Distributionally robust free energy principle for decision-making
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67348-6Autonomous agents can misbehave when training and environment conditions become inconsistent. Here, the authors introduce a Distributionally Robust Free Energy model that embeds robustness directly into the agent decision-making mechanisms through free energy minimization.

title: Agonist signaling drives neutrophil subpopulations to promote/inhibit colorectal cancer liver metastasis
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67579-7Liver metastasis remains a leading cause of colorectal cancer mortality. This study identifies different neutrophil subtypes involved in metastasis, highlighting therapeutic potential of neutrophil subset targeting to inhibit tumor progression.

title: PhaseT3M: 3D imaging at 1.6 Å resolution via electron cryo-tomography with nonlinear phase retrieval
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67303-5Electron tomography enables high-resolution 3D imaging but is limited by radiation sensitivity. Here, the authors demonstrate a phase retrieval method using multiple tilted HRTEM focal series, achieving 1.6 Å resolution with improved dose efficiency and elemental sensitivity.

title: Single-cell dynamics of genome-nucleolus interactions captured by nucleolar laser microdissection (NoLMseq)
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66294-7This study introduces NoLMseq, a method to map genome-nucleolus contacts in single cells, revealing stem cell populations with diverse chromatin states, the monoallelicity of these interactions, and how nucleolar stress reshapes 3D genome organization.

title: Denosumab attenuates knee osteoarthritis progression by inhibiting synovial inflammation via the RANK/TRAF6/FSTL1 signalling
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66202-zSynovitis is a key early driver of osteoarthritis (OA), and RANKL contributes to cartilage degradation in OA. Here the authors show that denosumab, an anti-RNKL antibody, reduces synovitis and delays OA progression in animal models and patients.

title: Enantio-selective vibronic coupling revealed via dissymmetry of upconverted emission in double-resonance excitation of chiral polymer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67211-8Nonlinear optical processes involving both vibrational and electronic transitions provide valid tools to resolve vibronic coupling in molecules. Here, the authors demonstrate double-resonance three-photon excitations enabling enantio-selective vibronic coupling and modulation of upconverted emission in a chiral medium.

title: ENSO impacts on marine ecosystems and fisheries in the tropical and South Atlantic
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 18 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00742-2The influence of the El Niño–Southern Oscillation on Atlantic marine systems and fisheries is complex. This Review outlines the mechanisms by which El Niño–Southern Oscillation impacts the tropical and South Atlantic, connecting physical climate perturbations to biogeochemical and ecological responses.

title: Beyond the Global Plastics Treaty
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00752-0Although the latest round of Global Plastics Treaty negotiations ended without agreement, the process has mobilized research, funding, and public engagement. Rather than waiting for an agreement, governments and communities should sustain momentum and build readiness for a future treaty through coordinated national planning, ambitious policies, and local initiatives.

title: Intelligent vision-guided trajectory reconstruction enables rapid localization and characterization of the Chang’E-6 landing site
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03074-7A high-fidelity reconstruction of the Chang’E-6 landing trajectory based on descent imagery can rapidly and accurately locate the landing site and be used for geological analyses including crater morphometry and regolith mineralogy.

title: Microbial iron cycling illuminates the biological contribution and potential climate drivers of deep-sea rare earth element enrichment
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03100-8Microbial iron cycling can enhance the accumulation of rare earth elements and yttrium in host minerals by facilitating their release from iron oxides back into the pore water, according to an integrated geochemical, magnetic, and microscopic analysis.

title: Dam-driven phosphorus sinks reversed the anticipated increase in phosphorus export from the Yangtze River Basin
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03087-2Dam-assisted phosphorus retention occurs in a considerable amount along the terrestrial aquatic continuum within the Yangtze River Basin, suggesting it be included in terrestrial biogeochemical and watershed models

title: Non-linear relationships between air temperature and river water quality revealed by a panel dataset of 276 Chinese cities
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02978-8Both single-day high temperatures and heatwaves significantly increase river permanganate index, worsening organic compound pollution, and contribute to quality-based water scarcity, according to an analysis of air temperature on river water quality in 276 Chinese cities from 2014- 2020.

title: Diverse genesis of early Earth’s continental crust hints the geodynamic transition at about 3.0 Gyrs ago
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02973-zPressure plays a primary role in controlling the formation and compositional diversity of tonalite-trondhjemite-granodiorite suites, with “high-pressure” variants derived from fluid-fluxed melting during subduction, recording the onset of global subduction at ~3.0 Ga, according to thermodynamic-geochemical modeling and mineral hygrometry analysis.

title: Atypical warming pattern of strong 2023-24 El Niño boosts global temperatures to new 1.5 °C record
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02971-1The 2023-24 El Niño event led global mean surface temperatures to surpass 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels, according to analysis of surface air temperature and ocean heat content data.

title: Relatively open vegetation landscapes promoted early Pleistocene hominin evolution
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02983-xRelatively open vegetation landscapes during the early Pleistocene facilitated hominins’ evolution, with resource abundance, accessibility, and mobility playing crucial roles, according to pollen analysis and quantitative reconstruction of vegetation openness.

title: Signatures of localization control transition between rupture styles on basaltic megathrusts
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02979-7Evolution of slow slip to dynamic rupture on seabed megathrusts in basalt can be explained by strain localization and a transition to strain weakening behaviour encoded as a microtextural signature in triaxial shear experiments on oceanic basalt gouge.

title: Interstep compatibility of a model for the prebiotic synthesis of RNA consistent with Hadean natural history

title: I’ve earned my PhD — what now?
summary: Nature, Published online: 17 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03489-4A chemist faces a classic early-career dilemma: what should they do next, and how do they start?

title: Safety regulations for cloning and a compass that finds true north
summary: Nature, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03740-yScientists discuss concerns that genetic manipulation could lead to disease outbreaks, and Nature is gifted an unusual scientific instrument, in our weekly dip into the archive.

title: Science’s role in my Great British Sewing Bee success
summary: Nature, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03536-0A research background and a passion for sewing inspired by her father helped Yasmin Proctor-Kent to reach the finals of the 2025 television competition.

title: Scientists skip key US meetings — and seize on smaller alternatives
summary: Nature, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04083-4Researchers are devising creative ways to get together as Trump’s policies curb travel to US gatherings.

title: How my institution strengthened research despite chronic underfunding
summary: Nature, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04050-zNurturing research talent at community-rooted universities and colleges is a necessity, not a luxury.

title: AI is transforming the economy — understanding its impact requires both data and imagination
summary: Nature, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04053-wControlled studies capture only a fraction of the effects of artificial intelligence. Economists should work with social scientists to find innovative ways to fully grasp this fast-moving field.

title: Autistic voices are an overlooked minority in geosciences
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01882-2Autism remains an under-recognized and under-represented aspect of inclusivity conversations in geosciences. We highlight an urgent need for support and recognition of autistic learners, alongside a need to integrate autistic voices in learning and teaching practices.

title: Retraction Note: Nanomedicines reveal how PBOV1 promotes hepatocellular carcinoma for effective gene therapy
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67606-7Retraction Note: Nanomedicines reveal how PBOV1 promotes hepatocellular carcinoma for effective gene therapy

title: The ribosome derives the energy to translocate and unwind mRNA from EF-G binding
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66812-7Ribosomes convert chemical energy to mechanical work. Here, the authors monitor ribosome binding to the GTPase EF-G and the ensuing mechanical work on mRNA in real time, uncovering a major energetic contribution from EF-G binding, rather than GTP hydrolysis, to the mechanical work.

title: Molecular basis of XPF-ERCC1 targeting to SLX4-dependent DNA repair pathways
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67216-3Structure-specific endonucleases play an important role in several DNA repair pathways. Here the authors present structures of the endonuclease XPF-ERCC1 in complex with SLX4, SLX4IP, and DNA. Combined with functional analysis, these results provide insight into the mechanisms of XPF-ERCC1 recruitment and activation during DNA repair.

title: Integration of affective cues in context-rich and dynamic scenes varies across individuals
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67466-1Here, the authors examine how people combine facial expressions and context to understand others’ emotions. They find that most people use a Bayesian integration strategy, where cues are weighted based on ambiguity, but others use more simplistic averaging strategies.

title: Multi-layered transcriptional control of glycogen metabolism coordinates thermogenic remodeling of white adipocytes in male mice
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67515-9Previous studies suggested that glycogen metabolism played a role in beiging of subcutaneous adipocytes. This work identifies a β-adrenergic–driven transcriptional program that promotes glycogen synthesis and turnover during thermogenic activation of adipocytes. PGC1α and estrogen-related receptors (ERRs) cooperatively sustain this program by regulating chromatin accessibility and gene expression.

title: Past and future change in global river flows
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00745-zHuman influence on the climate and terrestrial systems is increasingly altering global river flow. This Review discusses past and projected changes in global river flow, with an emphasis on annual volumes, seasonal dynamics and sudden changes in flow dynamics.

title: Advancing an adaptable and practical framework to address water quality challenges in a changing world
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00753-zAs water-quality challenges intensify, the widely used Weighted Regressions on Time, Discharge, and Season (WRTDS) method offers an adaptable and practical framework for global water-quality science and management.

title: Regulate reality in vehicle emission policy
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03093-4Vehicle emission standards have long been based on laboratory tests. This comment argues that policymakers now can and should regulate vehicles also based on real-world data. Europe’s performance-based regulation of plug-in hybrid vehicles can help develop more adaptive and evidence-based policies for transportation, energy, and environment.

title: Climate and sedimentary structure drive deep labile carbon accumulation in alpine wetlands
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03081-8Deep sediments ( < 1 meter) in alpine wetlands on the Qinghai-Xizang Plateau store about 70% of total organic carbon, much of it labile; past warming and clay–silt–clay layering enhanced deep carbon burial, as shown for wetlands in this region.

title: Moisture from US Corn Belt fuels more intense convective storms
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03089-0The groundwater-crop-irrigation interactions across the US Corn Belt amplify convective storm frequency, extend storm lifetime, and accelerate storm movement, based on a high-resolution regional climate model coupled with an advanced water vapor tracer.

title: Text-based modeling reveals the sector-specific benefits of emerging technologies for extreme flood adaptation
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03077-4Drones and online rescue forms lead to broad flood recovery, while navigation apps and drainage target traffic and buildings, according to text-mining modeling of millions of posts revealing sector-specific technology impacts and adaptation pathways.

title: Blue carbon sequestration and storage potential has increased in seagrass sediments from Northern Morocco
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02966-yCarbon accumulation rates in seagrass sediments in Northern Morocco have increased in recent years, according to sediment core analysis from coastal vegetated ecosystems in Northern Morocco.

title: Phreatic eruptions at Whakaari Volcano driven by hydrothermal mineralisation and magmatic gas input
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03057-8Phreatic eruptions at Whakaari volcano are influenced by subsurface pressurisation magnitudes and timescales, which are significantly influenced by hydrothermal mineralisation and magmatic gas input rates, according to 3-dimensional numerical modelling of volcanic hydrothermal systems.

title: Accelerating sea level rise in Africa and its large marine ecosystems since the 1990s
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02965-zSea-level rise in African large marine ecosystem has accelerated markedly since 2010, mostly due to ice sheet loss and land subsidence, with the Red Sea and Guinea Current rising fastest, according to an analysis of 30 years of satellite altimetry data

title: Giving a voice to animals: Laos’s national herpetologist on her day-to-day
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04054-9Somphouthone Phimmachak studies amphibians and reptiles as one of the country’s few conservation researchers.

title: How fasting boosts breast cancer therapy
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03809-8A discovery in mice reveals why fasting enhances a type of breast cancer treatment — a hormone-signalling pathway and gene-expression changes have key roles.

title: NSF softens grant-review rules to cope with backlog
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04067-4Agency staff members say that the changes are reasonable, but they are worried about the potential effects on review.

title: The best science images of 2025 — Nature’s picks
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03935-3The Sun’s fiery surface, a tattooed tardigrade, rare red lightning and more.

title: Despite all the negatives, 2025 showcased the power, resilience and universality of science
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04049-6There were huge disruptions to the global scientific enterprise this year — but immense bright spots for health, discovery, innovation and research collaboration.

title: Grant cuts, arrests, lay-offs: Trump made 2025 a tumultuous year for science
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04051-yHow the Trump administration caused seismic disruptions to the world’s premier scientific superpower.

title: Tracing pollution in the lives of Arctic seabirds
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03078-5Olivier Chastel travels to Svalbard in northern Norway to study the impact of contaminants such as mercury on black-legged kittiwakes.

title: More than half of researchers now use AI for peer review — often against guidance
summary: Nature, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04066-5Policies should reflect the ‘new reality’ of researchers’ increasing reliance on tools that can summarize manuscripts and draft reports.

title: Poleward migration of tropical cyclones over 1980–2024 is dominated by Pacific variability
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01866-2A tripolar pattern of Pacific sea surface temperature variability strongly modulates tropical cyclone latitudes and largely determined their poleward migration during the period 1980–2024, according to a data-model analysis.

title: Author Correction: Long non-coding RNA Linc-RAM enhances myogenic differentiation by interacting with MyoD
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64348-4Author Correction: Long non-coding RNA Linc-RAM enhances myogenic differentiation by interacting with MyoD

title: Mechanism of alternative splicing of yeast HEH1 through competing 5’ splice sites
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67659-8Here the authors show that alternative splicing of yeast HEH1 precursor mRNA with competing 5’ splice sites requires optimum decoding of the two sites by U5 and U6 snRNAs, supported by specific proteins of B and Bact spliceosomes, implying that closely spaced sites are used for alternative splicing in the core spliceosome.

title: Accurate imputation of pathway-specific gene expression in spatial transcriptomics with PASTA
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67421-0Numerous methods predict unmeasured gene expression in spatial transcriptomics data, but most focus on individual genes and yield variable results. Here, the authors present an approach that leverages cell type and spatial context for robust pathway expression prediction.

title: Reconstruction and analysis of pore blockage fouling in ceramic ultrafiltration membranes through FIB-SEM
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67662-zHere authors develop a focused ion beam-scanning electron microscopy tomography strategy that enables accurate 3D reconstruction of organic foulant accumulation within ceramic ultrafiltration membrane pores.

title: LncRNA CISTR-ACT regulates cell size in human and mouse by guiding FOSL2
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67591-xEstablishment and maintenance of appropriate cell size is a prerequisite for cells to function efficiently. Here, Kiriakopulos et al. reveal that the lncRNA CISTR-ACT maintains cell size across cell types in humans and mice by regulating cell morphogenesis genes in trans via guidance of the transcription factor FOSL2.

title: Ovarian cancer metastasis to the human omentum disrupts organ homeostasis and induces fundamental tissue reprogramming
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 16 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67557-zThe omentum is the main metastatic site for ovarian cancer. Here, the authors present a human cell atlas of both benign and omentum metastatic ovarian cancer, providing insights into established metastatic sites but also of the omentum pre-metastatic niche.

title: Author Correction: Strong crystalline thermal insulation induced by extended antibonding states
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67432-xAuthor Correction: Strong crystalline thermal insulation induced by extended antibonding states

title: Author Correction: Macrophage lineage cells-derived migrasomes activate complement-dependent blood-brain barrier damage in cerebral amyloid angiopathy mouse model
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67562-2Author Correction: Macrophage lineage cells-derived migrasomes activate complement-dependent blood-brain barrier damage in cerebral amyloid angiopathy mouse model

title: Deep Gulf of Mexico seeps are not a significant source of methane to the atmosphere
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03027-0Gulf of Mexico hydrocarbon seeps deeper than 400 m are not a major contributor to marine atmospheric methane emissions, according to analyses of the concentration and natural radiocarbon content of methane dissolved in seawater above Gulf of Mexico hydrocarbon vents.

title: Quantifying land-use metrics for solar photovoltaic projects in the western United States
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02862-5In the western US, the land-use implications of solar panel installations vary by region and system design, with an average capacity-based land-use efficiency of 24.7 watts per square meter and a mean land transformation of 0.846 square meters per megawatt-hour, according to a machine learning analysis.

title: Compounding preconditions of wildfires vary in time and space within Europe
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02955-1Wildfire activity in Europe is driven by various compounding conditions, dominated by drought conditions and vapor pressure deficit, according to an integrated analysis of land-surface parameters and hydro-meteorological drivers.

title: Sustainability pathways enable China’s marine economic sectors to reach a 2030 emissions peak
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 15 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02967-xGreenhouse gas emissions from China’s marine economic sector have increased 2000-2020, but sustainability pathways can ensure a peak in emissions by 2030, according to combined life- cycle assessment and scenario projections.

title: Enhanced marine primary productivity during the long-term Ordovician cooling: A barium isotope perspective from South China
summary: Publication date: 1 February 2026Source: Earth and Planetary Science Letters, Volume 675Author(s): Shengchao Yang, Junxuan Fan, Chao Li, Yi-Bo Lin, Yiying Deng, Zongyuan Sun, Jian Cao, Shu-zhong Shen
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Earth and Planetary Science Letters

authors:

César R. Ranero,

Arantza Ugalde
summary: Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth, Volume 130, Issue 12, December 2025.
source: Wiley: Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth: Table of Contents

title: Slower-growing species promote interspecific cooperation and coexistence under acid stress through cross-feeding
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67395-zAcid stress is an environmental factor shaping the structure and function of microbial communities. Here, the authors show that microbial interspecific interactions are highly dynamic during acid stress changes. They find slow-growing species promote population cooperation and coexistence under elevated acid stress.

title: Visualizing insecticide control of insect TRP channel function and assembly
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67287-2The heteromeric insect TRPV channel, Nanchung-Inactive, is a previously structurally uncharacterized insecticide target. Here, Fedor et al. provide insights into how an insecticide and a natural agonist modulate channel behavior, paving the way for future insecticide development.

title: Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist in large vessel occlusion treated by reperfusion therapy—a phase 2 randomized trial
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66167-zSemaglutide, a GLP-1 receptor agonist, may offer neuroprotective benefits after stroke, but its effects in large vessel occlusion (LVO) are unknown. Here the authors show, in a phase 2 randomized trial, that semaglutide is safe after endovascular therapy and may improve recovery in patients not receiving intravenous thrombolysis.

title: Flexible robotic hand harnesses large deformations for full-coverage human-like multimodal haptic perception
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67148-yWhile visual-tactile sensors promise high perception resolution at low cost, they often sacrifice compliance to maintain optical stability, hindering non-planar contact perception. The authors present FlexiRay, a soft gripper merging visual-tactile sensing with a compliant Fin Ray structure.

title: All-optical hybrid metasurfaces for ultrafast computational spectrometer and single-pixel imaging
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67605-8A hybrid metasurface functioning as a low-correlation and ultrafast spectral/spatial light modulator is demonstrated for all-optical THz computational spectrometer and single pixel imaging replacing mechanical delay lines and coherent detection.

title: Structural characterisation of the fungal Pmt4 homodimer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67412-1PMTs are fungal O-mannosyltransferases embedded in the ER membrane. Here, structures of the Pmt4 homodimer reveal distinct features of this PMT family and uncover an additional cytosolic binding site for the Dol-P-Man substrate lipid.

title: The microRNA miR-71 suppresses maladaptive UPR<sup>mt</sup> signaling through both cell-autonomous and cell-non-autonomous mechanisms
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67198-2Mitochondria play roles in sensing environmental and physiological stress, but their response can become maladaptive during chronic stress. Here they identify a protective miRNA response in C. elegans that maintains tissue health by attenuating mitochondrial stress signaling.

title: Targeting LRBA triggers CTLA4 degradation and antitumor immunity for cancer immunotherapy
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67365-5LRBA deficiency is associated with autoimmune disease and CTLA4 loss; this study identifies LRBA as a negative regulator of antitumor immunity and introduces LC427 as a promising small-molecule inhibitor of the CTLA4-LRBA interaction for cancer immunotherapy.

title: Global rural settlement expansion rivals its urban counterpart in biodiversity impact
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 14 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03082-7Globally, overlooked rural settlement expansion contributes more to biodiversity decline than urban sprawl, according to an analysis that combines data on urban and rural settlements, land use, and species distribution.

title: Expanding compound heat and ultraviolet radiation stress amplifies exposure risks for elderly populations
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03070-xCentral Asia, North Africa, and India have historically experienced frequent combined heat and high ultraviolet radiation stress, and by the end of this century, population exposure is expected to increase across emission scenarios, according to climate, ultraviolet index, and demographic data.

summary: Publication date: Available online 13 December 2025Source: Geochimica et Cosmochimica ActaAuthor(s): Davide Mariani, Riccardo Tribuzio, Tong Liu, Fu-Yuan Wu, Alberto Zanetti
source: ScienceDirect Publication: Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta

title: SARS-CoV-2 within-host population expansion, diversification and adaptation in zoo tigers, lions and hyenas
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66402-7This paper describes within-host evolutionary dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 during an outbreak in three carnivore species. Positive selection and the emergence of potentially species-specific mutations were observed in lion and hyena samples.

title: Pressure and bias dependence of the rate-limiting steps of the oxygen reduction reaction
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67494-xElectrocatalytic multi-step reactions are very complex. Here, the authors report that the oxygen reduction reaction cascades through a series of rate-limiting steps that are linked to the bias- and pressure-dependent catalyst-solution interface.

title: Shell-isolated nanoparticle-enhanced femtosecond stimulated Raman spectroscopy reveals ultrafast molecular dynamics of surface reactions
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66454-9Shell-isolated nanoparticle enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SHINERS) has enhanced the sensitivity of Raman spectroscopy for applications in materials and life sciences. Here, the authors develop its femtosecond stimulated version (SHINE-FSRS) for in-situ monitoring of molecular dynamics on ultrafast scales.

title: Why covalent organic frameworks grow twisted on graphite
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67598-4Van der Waals two dimensional materials made of graphene and covalent organic frameworks have potential for advanced electronics applications and a fundamental understanding of the formation process of these materials is desirable. Here, the authors revealed the main aspects that influence the twisted stacking growth of pyrene diboronic acid covalent organic frameworks on graphite with a hybrid molecular mechanics force field.

title: Mechanosensor-mediated Hsp70 phosphorylation orchestrates the landscape of the heat shock response
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67204-7Cells must sense heat quickly to protect their proteins and membranes. Here, the authors show that membrane stretch detected by the membrane sensor Mid2 promotes rapid phosphorylation of the Hsp70 chaperone to coordinate gene activity, protein synthesis and resolution of stress-induced protein droplets during heat shock.

title: Direct observations of cross-scale energy transfer driven by multiple-ion interactions in space plasmas
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66374-8The study provides observational evidence of energy transfer in space plasmas, showing hydrogen and helium ions interact differently with ion-scale waves. Despite helium’s low abundance, they show their interaction can excite electrostatic waves, facilitating energy transfer across scales and challenging traditional models.

title: Integrating dry-processing and pre-sodiation enables high-energy sodium ion batteries
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66492-3Using sacrificial salts to enhance sodium-ion batteries is hampered by practical issues. Here, authors demonstrate a solvent-free dry-processing method that ensures complete salt decomposition for major gains in energy density and lifespan.

title: Targeted CRISPR-Cas9 screening identifies core transcription factors controlling murine haemato-endothelial fate commitment
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66230-9During development, blood is generated in the yolk sac by differentiation of haemato-endothelial mesoderm into haematopoietic progenitors. Using CRISPR-Cas9 screens, the authors identify Etv2, Smad1, Ldb1, Six4 and Zbtb7b as regulators of haemato-endothelial mesoderm commitment. Lack of these regulators gave rise to mesodermal subsets with a defined lineage differentiation bias.

title: Melting of old refractory mantle during subduction initiation of the western Pacific plate
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 13 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02987-7Re-melting of both ancient and younger refractory lithospheric mantle contributed to the generation of Izu–Bonin forearc basalts during the earliest stages of subduction initiation, according to hafnium–neodymium isotope analyses.

title: Urban population exposure to apparent temperature whiplash is projected to increase with global warming
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03066-7Over the past 80 years, urban areas have experienced more apparent-temperature whiplash events, and projections suggest that their frequency, along with the affected population, will continue to grow, especially under higher-emission scenarios, according to climate models and observations.

title: Melt inclusions reveal massive carbon dioxide emissions from continental intraplate volcanism
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02958-yOlivine-hosted melt inclusions from the Bas-Vivarais volcanic province (Massif Central, France) exhibit unusually high carbon dioxide concentrations, up to 4.8 percent by weight, and are among the highest ever measured to date, according to data inferred from the high-pressure homogenization technique.

summary: Nature, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04052-xIn a world that can seem lacking in optimism, researchers share their opinions on books that stimulate thoughts — and actions — for a better future.

title: Science sleuths raise concerns about scores of bioengineering papers
summary: Nature, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03870-3Prominent bioengineer Ali Khademhosseini has so far corrected more than 40 of the papers in question, but critics say some should have been retracted.

title: Revised estimates of CO<sub>2</sub> sources and sinks improve global carbon accounting
summary: Nature, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03981-xUpdated estimates of the worldwide sources and sinks of anthropogenic carbon dioxide provide a firmer basis for monitoring climate action.

title: China leads research in 90% of crucial technologies — a dramatic shift this century

title: Sedimentary conditions drive modern pyrite burial flux to exceed oxidation
summary: Nature Geoscience, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41561-025-01855-5Modern pyrite burial in seafloor sediments exceeds pyrite oxidation on land, indicating that the sulfur cycle is out of balance, and acts to increase atmospheric oxygen levels, according to a diagenetic model validated by sediment cores.

title: Infant gut anellovirus composition associates with early life factors and childhood atopic disease
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66732-6Here, the authors characterize the gut virome of 647 one-year-old children in the COPSAC2010 cohort, finding that anelloviruses are highly prevalent and associated with daycare attendance, gestational age, and FUT2 secretor status.

title: Redox-Improved Self-Assembled Monolayers for Inverted Perovskite Solar Cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66421-4Variations in the valence states of nickel oxide hinder the growth of a uniform self-assembled monolayer (SAM). Here, authors develop a SAM with the oxidized product forming S−O−Ni bond at Ni3+-rich regions, achieving maximum device efficiency of 26.5% in operationally stable perovskite solar cells.

title: Isofrequency spin-wave imaging using color center magnetometry for magnon spintronics
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67056-1Color center magnetometry enables spin-wave imaging in complex magnetic textures. This work overcomes key limitations of current approaches by decoupling sensor spins from control fields and using diamond and hBN color centers for complementary frequency operation, achieving isofrequency imaging of field-controlled spin waves.

title: Supersolidophobic Pt catalyst for long-term natural seawater electrolysis with hydrogen production and magnesium extraction
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66473-6Electrochemical synthesis of solid compounds is an emerging frontier in electrocatalysis. Here, the authors report a Pt catalyst whose surface-coordinated halogens alleviate the scaling effect by regulating the local environment and enable simultaneous Mg(OH)₂ and H₂ production from natural seawater.

title: Concurrent TB and HIV therapies control TB reactivation during co-infection but not chronic immune activation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67188-4The basis for inefficient Mtb control in PLWH despite treatment is unclear. Here, the authors show that combined TB/HIV therapy in Mtb/SIV co-infected macaques reduces bacterial and viral burden and improved lung pathology, but failed to fully restore immune balance, revealing persistent inflammation.

title: The long non-coding RNA UGDH-AS1 encodes an NK-cell-inhibiting micropeptide in triple-negative breast cancers
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66266-xDysfunctional NK cells contribute to the immune-hostile tumour microenvironment of triple-negative breast cancers (TNBC). Here authors show that NKSM, a micropeptide encoded by the long non-coding RNA UGDH-AS1, is specifically expressed in the intra-tumoral NK cells in TNBC and interferes with their anti-tumour activity.

title: Hyperglycemia exacerbates osteoarthritis by impairing macrophage efferocytosis through modulation of CD11b lactylation
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67473-2Diabetes, a frequent co-morbidity to osteoarthritis, accelerates progression of joint inflammation. Here author show that hyperglycaemia enhances glycolysis in synovial macrophages, leading to increased lactylation of CD11b, which impairs the capacity of macrophages to phagocytose apoptotic cells, which eventually aggravates inflammation.

title: Mediators of the association between psychological distress and mortality in people diagnosed with cancer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 12 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66059-2Psychological distress is associated with a range of adverse outcomes in people living with and beyond cancer (LWBC). In here, the authors find that psychological distress is associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cancer mortality in people with LWBC, partly due to high systemic inflammation. However, evidence for mediation by health behaviours is found to be inconsistent.

title: Super-resolution wind mapping with deep learning for scalable renewable energy planning
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03072-9Super-resolution wind mapping is possible through combined frequency-based filtering and generative adversarial architecture, suggests a deep learning-based framework validated with a point-to-grid Monte Carlo evaluation scheme

title: Modelling of earthquake swarms suggests magmatic fluids in the upper crust beneath the Eger Rift
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03019-0A seismic swarm on the Czech/German border in 2024 began with an initial phase of hydro-fracturing followed by a higher magnitude phase of fault slip and hydro-shearing, resolved from a high-resolution seismic catalogue and fluid intrusion models.

title: Terrestrial atmospheric ion implantation occurred in the nearside lunar regolith during the history of Earth’s dynamo
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02960-4Numerical simulations reveal that the transfer of ions from Earth’s atmosphere to the Moon is efficient only in the sustained presence of a geomagnetic field, suggesting that lunar soils may record the histories of the atmosphere, solar wind, and geodynamo.

title: Structures of human glucose-6-phosphate transporter reveal reciprocal antiport mechanism driving glucose-6-phosphate and inorganic phosphate exchange

Here the authors show that BPTF is upregulated in prostate cancer cells, increases chromatin accessibility at Androgen Receptor (AR)-binding sites, and stabilizes the AR-FOXA1 complex.

title: High single-pass conversion of nitrous oxide to dinitrogen in gas-diffusion-electrolyzer
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67244-zEfficient single-pass conversion poses a challenge in N2O electroreduction. Here, the authors report a gas-diffusion-electrolyzer system using a CuAg catalyst that achieves 79.4% single-pass N2O conversion, offering a cost-effective pathway for greenhouse gas mitigation.

title: Curvature-engineered interfacial hydrogen-bond networks driving proton-coupled electron transfer boosts hydrogen oxidation in alkaline fuel cells
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66360-0The sluggish hydrogen oxidation reaction hinders the development of anion exchange membrane fuel cells. Here, the authors develop high-curvature RuIr CNCs that induce an O-down water orientation, thereby strengthening hydrogen-bond networks and reducing proton transfer barriers.

title: Mechanistic insights into single-stranded DNA degradation by lysosomal exonucleases PLD3 and PLD4 from structural snapshots
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66261-2PLD3 and PLD4 are endolysosomal exonucleases that modulate TLR7 and TLR9 responses. The authors report cryoEM structures capturing distinct catalytic states, providing mechanistic insights into single-stranded DNA degradation by PLD3 and PLD4.

title: Enhanced tunable X-rays from bulk crystals driven by table-top free electron energies
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66063-6The authors demonstrate tunable x-ray generation from free-electron-driven van der Waals bulk crystals. This overturns the notion that parametric x-rays are only possible with very thin films or highly relativistic electrons and show record enhancement of the x-ray output.

title: Topological quantum cascade laser with Dirac-scaled valley edge modes
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66525-xTopological lasers offer robust performance but often at the cost of a large non-lasing bulk. Here, the authors propose a Dirac-scaled quantum cascade laser that expands the lasing mode volume while maintaining robustness against structural defects.

title: Co-condensation between transcription factor and cBAF selectively modulates chromatin remodeling and gene expression
summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-67322-2Activation of genes depends on transcription factors and chromatin remodelers. Here, the authors show ARID1A organizes these components through phase separation, co-condensing with specific transcription factors to maintain chromatin accessibility and drive gene expression.

title: Glacier biogeochemical cycling and downstream impacts
summary: Nature Reviews Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43017-025-00751-1Far from frozen and sterile environments, glaciers are biogeochemical reactors and regulators. This Review outlines key biogeochemical and associated physical processes occurring in glacierized environments and the known impacts of glaciers on elemental cycling and the Earth system.

title: Ecological levers for microbially driven water treatment enhance pollutant removal prediction
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02996-6Microbial ecological indicators significantly enhance pollutant removal prediction by 37% compared to models based only on process parameters, according to a machine-learned framework developed with performance data across 648 globally distributed biofilters.

title: Cross-continental soil prokaryotic traits driven by precipitation regime and land cover
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-03028-zSmall genomes and high maximal growth of soil prokaryotes occurred in barren soils and soils with high precipitation seasonality, while large genomes and low growth appeared in moist, resource-rich forests, based on marker gene-based trait analysis of samples from Greenland, Europe, and South Africa.

title: Strong impact of tropical cyclones on the genesis of subsurface marine heatwaves
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02992-wTropical cyclones trigger up to 40% of subsurface marine heatwaves in cyclone-active regions, according to in situ observations and ocean reanalysis, which also suggests their area and intensity have increased over the past two decades due to long-term ocean warming.

title: Characterizing the vertical structure of forests in the Brazilian Amazon
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02976-wVertical structure of forests in the Brazilian Amazon varies with secondary forest age and is affected by multiple disturbances, and forests in the region can be classified into 5 types, according to an airborne LiDAR dataset covering over 188,000 hectares.

title: Interaction of multiple triggering mechanisms during the 2023 Jishishan earthquake sequence
summary: Communications Earth & Environment, Published online: 11 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s43247-025-02985-9Finite source modelling using geodetic and teleseismic data suggest that aftershocks on the main fault were triggered primarily by static stress changes, whereas those along the conjugate fault network were driven by volumetric strain and fluid injection

title: Glimmers of hope for a deadly disease
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03941-5New models, efforts for early detection and better therapies may help change pancreatic cancer’s aggressive course.

title: Will young universities set the pace in the age of AI?
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03949-xWhy some institutions are betting on technology to stay relevant.

title: Exposing a silent cancer
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03942-4Pancreatic cancer is one of the deadliest malignancies, and it is increasingly occurring in young people — especially women. An uptick in research funding is a welcome development in the push to transform treatment.

title: Neanderthals mastered fire — 400,000 years ago
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04059-4Archaeological evidence makes a compelling case for Neanderthal-created fires 400,000 years ago in Suffolk, UK — plus, how chatbots can sway the opinions of voters.

title: Fasting boosts breast cancer therapy efficacy via glucocorticoid activation
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09869-0Beneficial effects of fasting combined with endocrine therapy for oestrogen receptor-α-expressing breast cancers can be recapitulated using exogenous glucocorticoid receptor ligands instead of fasting to reduce harmful effects.

title: The influence of short-lived halogens on atmospheric chemistry and climate
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09753-xA Review of the impacts of short-lived halogens on air quality and climate identifies gaps in our knowledge of short-lived halogen emissions, chemistry, and the environmental and climate impacts.

title: Quantifying grain boundary deformation mechanisms in small-grained metals
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09800-7Experimental observations in small-grained polycrystals suggest a new concept of considering metallic grain boundaries not as defects but as separate defect-containing lattices, providing a potential explanation for the deformation behaviour of nanocrystalline metals.

title: Gene-drive-capable mosquitoes suppress patient-derived malaria in Tanzania
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09685-6Engineering of local Anopheles gambiae under containment enables the generation of a transgenic strain equipped with non-autonomous gene drive capabilities that robustly inhibits genetically diverse Plasmodium falciparum isolates obtained from naturally infected children.

title: Erythropoietin receptor on cDC1s dictates immune tolerance
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09824-zThe tolerogenic activity of type 1 conventional dendritic cells (cDC1s) is determined by EPOR, which is preferentially expressed in cDC1s and induces antigen-specific FOXP3-expressing regulatory T cells.

title: Human gut M cells resemble dendritic cells and present gluten antigen
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09829-8An intestinal organoid model recapitulates human microfold (M) cell function and transcriptomic profiling and biochemical assays demonstrate that M cells uptake and present antigens to the immune system via the class II major histocompatibility complex.

title: Cross-regulation of [2Fe–2S] cluster synthesis by ferredoxin-2 and frataxin
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09822-1A finely balanced ratio of ferredoxin-2 (FDX2) and frataxin (FXN) is essential for the synthesis of iron–sulfur clusters, and interventions targeting this ratio could provide a way to treat related diseases, such as Friedreich’s ataxia.

title: Sterilization and contraception increase lifespan across vertebrates
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09836-9Data collected from zoos and aquariums worldwide show that hormonal contraception or permanent surgical sterilization in mammals increase life expectancy, with different mechanisms in males and females.

title: Earliest evidence of making fire
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09855-6Baked sediment, heat-shattered artefacts and introduced pyrite in a 400,000-year-old Palaeolithic occupation site in Suffolk, UK provide evidence of intentional fire-making, marking a pivotal moment in human development.

title: Observation of deuteron and antideuteron formation from resonance-decay nucleons
authors: J. G. M. C. A. Arneiro
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09775-5The ALICE Collaboration provides details on the microscopic mechanism that ends up creating antideuteron in high-energy proton–proton collisions at the Large Hadron Collider.

title: Hot droughts in the Amazon provide a window to a future hypertropical climate
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09728-yThirty years of forest demographic data, combined with recent ecophysiological measurements, reveal that intense Amazon droughts sharply increase tree mortality once soil moisture falls below a threshold, and that these hot droughts will become more frequent and intense as Earth warms towards hypertropical conditions.

title: A direct role for a mitochondrial targeting sequence in signalling stress
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09834-xCells can sense mitochondrial damage through signalling via an unimported mitochondrial targeting sequence.

title: Neutrophils preserve energy storage in sympathetically activated adipocytes
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09839-6Neutrophil-derived IL-1β has a role in preserving lipid stores during metabolic stress.

title: Mapping the genetic landscape across 14 psychiatric disorders
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09820-3Genomic analyses applied to 14 childhood- and adult-onset psychiatric disorders identifies five underlying genomic factors that explain the majority of the genetic variance of the individual disorders.

title: An RNA splicing system that excises DNA transposons from animal mRNAs
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09853-8A new type of mRNA splicing mechanism discovered in Caenorhabditis elegans that detects and removes inverted repeats also occurs in human cells, thereby providing another strategy to protect against the negative effects of transposable elements.

title: Uncovering the role of LINE-1 in the evolution of lung adenocarcinoma
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09825-yLung adenocarcinomas bearing the ID2 mutational signature display increased LINE-1 retrotransposon activity, which contributes to their fast evolutionary dynamics and aggressive phenotype.

title: Somatic evolution following cancer treatment in normal tissue
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09792-4High-depth sequencing of non-cancerous tissue from patients with metastatic cancer reveals single-base mutational signatures of alcohol, smoking and cancer treatments, and reveals how exogenous factors, including cancer therapies, affect somatic cell evolution.

title: Protected area management has significant spillover effects on vegetation
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09837-8Analysis of effect sizes of vegetation spillovers from protected areas in Australia shows that 71% of over 3,063 analysed protected areas had a positive spillover effect, and that these effects covary with protected area management type.

title: Laser-based conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy of <sup>229</sup>ThO<sub>2</sub>
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09776-4Laser-induced conversion electron Mössbauer spectroscopy, which detects electrons emitted by 229Th nuclei in a thin ThO2 sample excited by vacuum ultraviolet light, is demonstrated, opening the possibility of a conversion-electron-based nuclear clock.

title: Agonists for cytosolic bacterial receptor ALPK1 induce antitumour immunity
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09828-9The ALPK1 agonist UDSP-Hep stimulates tumour-cell antigen presentation, macrophage–DC cross-priming and differentiation of protective memory T cells.

title: Causal modelling of gene effects from regulators to programs to traits
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09866-3Approaches combining genetic association and Perturb-seq data that link genetic variants to functional programs to traits are described.

title: Mutations in mitochondrial ferredoxin FDX2 suppress frataxin deficiency
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09821-2A forward genetic screen in Caenorhabditis elegans reveals that decreased levels of the ferredoxin FDX2 suppress the loss of frataxin in worms and in mice by relief of FDX2 inhibition of frataxin-stimulated NFS1 activity.

title: Gut micro-organisms associated with health, nutrition and dietary interventions
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09854-7Comprehensive large-scale studies of multi-national populations identified microbiome species consistently associated with favourable and unfavourable health markers, informing future studies of the human gut microbiome and its association with diet and cardiometabolic conditions.

title: Pancreatic cancer is evasive. Is the nervous system the reason why?
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03943-3A growing body of research suggests tumours rely on proteins and genes that are unique to the nervous system to persist in the body.

title: Six highlights from pancreatic cancer research
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03948-yUnpacking risk factors, disease aggressiveness and other key work.

title: What would an AI university look like and how might it change education?
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03950-4From lectures by avatars to entire qualifications, higher education centred around AI is just around the corner.

title: A breathalyser-style test for detecting pancreatic cancer
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03946-0Surgeon George Hanna is developing a non-invasive test to catch one of the deadliest cancers before it’s too late.

title: Is your brain tired? Researchers are discovering the roots of mental fatigue
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03974-wBetter ways to measure cognitive exhaustion could point to treatments for long COVID and other debilitating disorders.

title: A giant catalogue of microscopic species across Denmark
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03819-6The Microflora Danica project has catalogued the microbial diversity of environmental habitats across Denmark and established an improved taxonomic reference database. As well as providing a special record of nitrogen-oxidizing microorganisms, the data set serves as a national baseline for tracking future microbial responses to factors such as land-use change and global warming.

title: SOS: RNA-processing mechanism rescues genes from invasive DNA
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03734-wTransposable elements can insert into genes, disrupting protein-coding potential. Researchers discover a mode of RNA processing, ‘SOS splicing’, that provides a quick fix.

title: But only just
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04022-3Making scents of things.

title: The pancreatic cancer models helping to drive innovation in the field
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03944-2Cellular, animal and computational models of the disease are providing fresh insights into biology and treatment.

title: China is leading the world on AI governance: other countries must engage
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03972-yThe nation’s regulators are attempting to match the rapid pace at which AI is evolving. That needs to become a global initiative.

title: Four young universities share their strategies for success
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03951-3Nimble, responsive and collaborative, these institutions stand out in the Nature Index.

title: A simple slipknot for precise force control
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03829-4The tension of conventional surgical sutures can affect wound healing and is dependent on the surgeon’s experience. Imaging and simulations reveal that slipknots can reproducibly store and release force, enabling precise and consistent surgical knotting without the need for electronic sensors or specialized equipment.

title: Nuclear clocks could use electrical signals to keep time
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03732-yThe emission of photons by excited nuclei has been explored for timekeeping and sensing, but nuclear processes that eject electrons offer practical advantages.

title: Huge genetic study reveals hidden links between psychiatric conditions
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04037-wAnalysis of more than 1 million people shows that mental-health disorders fall into five clusters, each of them linked to a specific set of genetic variants.

title: Genetically engineered mosquitoes block development of circulating malaria strains
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03577-5The genetic engineering of mosquitoes offers a potentially transformative, self-sustaining opportunity for malaria control and elimination in Africa. By rendering mosquitoes unable to transmit the malaria parasite, even when they bite humans, the technology provides a mosquito-based intervention to complement existing efforts.

title: Therapeutic vaccines can challenge pancreatic cancer before it takes hold
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03947-zSpecific protein targets and personalized vaccines have the potential to increase survival rates for the disease.

title: The brain’s speech centre responds to universal and specific features of language
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03827-6More than 7,000 languages are spoken around the world, but the human brain becomes highly specialized to process speech in an individual’s own language. Recordings from human brains reveal the shared and language-specific neural mechanisms that arise in the superior temporal gyrus to achieve this feat.

title: Shared genetic risk in psychiatric disorders
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03728-8Scientists have characterized the broad genetic patterns that are shared across 14 psychiatric disorders. Could it reframe how mental-health conditions are diagnosed?

title: Early detection could improve pancreatic cancer’s poor survival rates
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03945-1The disease is often caught too late to affect a person’s prognosis — scientists are looking to change that.

title: Oldest known evidence of the controlled ignition of fire
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03735-9A 400,000-year-old site excavated in England reveals signs of deliberate fires made using the mineral iron pyrite to produce sparks.

title: A guide to the Nature Index
summary: Nature, Published online: 10 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03952-2A description of the terminology and methodology used in this supplement, and a guide to the functionality that is available free online at natureindex.com.
